reviewText: FTL could have been the ultimate bada.s.s. Star Trek game. The game draws inspiration from this franchise but is not a rip-off at all. It has enough style and lore by itself. I'll be brief: graphics are good, music is too (love how themes change when you enter battle mode - it's the same theme only more tense), story is made up by you - a rouge-like experience where no game session is similar. BUT! One word:  gameplay . It is so damn deep and addictive! I loose several hours in a row in it though I don't usually play a video game too long in one session. Battle system is especially awesome. It's of a sheer joy to participate in tactical exchange between two starships: you control systems and subsystems, fix damaged ones, choose the right time to fire different weapons, harass the enemy with combat drones... It feels like gold to break enemy's shields and then cut their hull with laser! FTL got different unique races, augmentations, unlockable ships... Advanced Edition which came out in April of 2014 added to the gameplay a lot - new features, races, updated hud. Hard to believe it was free too. Game is an absolute must-own for sci-fi fans. Everyone else, buy it too!

reviewText:
Completing a game of FTL is a satisfying victory I feel every self-respecting person should experience at least once. I thought that after I had beat the game one time, I would be done with it and move on to something else. That was not the case. I had continued to play the game over and over, trying to beat it with every ship and I had found myself even re-using ships I'd already beaten the game with. Simply put, the game has great replay-value.

After 100 hours of playing this game, FTL had become one of my all time favorite games. Some compare its gameplay to that of a rougelike, due to an incidental and randomized journey through space and of course: perma-death. However I'd say the game is too unique to be classified under any one genre, but it's definitely an exciting game of strategy and survival.

The game can be played at your own pace due to being able to pause and queue up commands at your own leisure, or it can be played as a brutally-challenging action-game that requires quick decisions. Even if you play the game slowly, it's still very difficult. The dastardly nature of the game makes it feel like all odds are against you and the only way to win is through sheer luck, but that is in fact not the case, as an experienced FTL player can beat the game (destroying the Flagship) consistently as long as they are careful and make the right choices. I've even wrote a detailed guide explaining this further.

Although the game play is simple in concept, you'll notice it is fairly in-depth. You command a cruiser with up to 8 people on board, ranging from humans to alien bugs to rockmen -- each with their own unique traits and stats; i.e. Rockmen are slow, hard to kill and immune to fire while Humans' unique trait is being boring". When you encounter an enemy cruiser
hoursPlayed: when given the opportunity: negotiate. You have an arsenal of offensive options at your disposal such as weapons

reviewText: An ever-changing game experience, with random events, numerous hidden storylines, and difficult-to-get unlockables makes the replay value on this game high and mighty. One could spend months, years at a time playing through FTL, and like a snowflake, never run into a repeat. That, coupled with the game's creative and beautiful collection of stories, artwork, and music makes for one of the greatest experiences anyone could hope to witness from even the best of this century's newest games.\nThe undeniable beauty makes the pain of losing bearable... The infinite choices gives you hope that you can avoid it... And the rare but unequaled sensation of self-fulfillment makes it all worth that one extra try.\nA true masterpiece.

reviewText: SPAAAAACE!!! No seriously, this game rocks asteroids. Adventure, micro-management, combat, strategy, everything is as polished as a Naboo Starfighter. There is a real sense of progression and achievement as you conquer increasingly difficult galaxies while building up the strength of your ship and crew. Combat is smart and relies not only on your current build but also on your ability to adapt your tactics to the current situation. FTL being a rogue-like there is also a bit of luck involved, but I didn't find that frustrating as randomness in FTL creates a sense of tension and helplessness that adds a lot to the atmosphere. All in all, FTL is a great game that's easy to understand but challenging to master and you'll enjoy every last bit of it, slugs, zoltans and all!

reviewText:
FTL: Faster than Light is a modern first person shooter set in the pre-historic era. Players team up with familiar faces such as Yoda from Cooking Mama: Hitler's Revenge, Dark Magician Girl from The Eldar Scrools: Minecraft, Kobe Bryant from Sleep Simulator 1966 and Cicero from Octodad: Ninja Warrior to battle against the evil forces of the Australian Government.

The main protagonist, Scratch Cat (Voiced by Dwayne Cena), leads his team of up to 7 cultists through Customs and Border Security as they try to free the Jewish slaves from the clutches of the Pharaoh with the help of Mike Tyson and the Duke of Deception whilst saving Christmas and trying to find Wally. The varying enemy types really brighten the song up as they provide the driver with new challenges at each turn. Personally, my favorite boss battle is the very first one against The Dynamic Duo; Sir. Lynch III and Dr. Breen where players are forced to endure being called an embarrassment for a whole month.

A few negatives that I have about the game are that there aren't a lot of choices on the menu and the water is too cold. These may be only minor things that may only affect some people but I feel that it is important that I identify these things.

Something that I feel I should point out to anyone interested in this recipe is that the PvP aspect of the game can be very challenging and confusing to newcomers of the country. Though being a FPS, the LoL PvP suddenly changes the game into an open world MMORPG where monkeys rule the earth. This sudden change has been reported to give trees cancer and thus, caution should be taken when accessing the PvP feature under the sea.

All in all, Fire Emblem: Awakening is a really well developed game with a passionate dev team. The car has great performance, gameplay, visuals and add a dash of salt to seal the deal. I really enjoyed my first lap and I feel as if many other would too. I give Watch Doge: New Vegas a score of 32.33 uh, repeating of course chicken nuggers out of 10.

reviewText: Let me start by addressing some of the complaints about this games such as it being all based on luck and how it lacks content. There is a huge amount, I would even go as far as saying an equal amount of strategy to this game as there is luck. From what you buy, to if you decide to buy anything at all and instead choose to upgrade your ship giving it that extra fire power or hiding behind your many layers of shields. There are so many different ways of playing this game and a large amount of content if you bother to use it. You are able to unlock new ships and new set ups from completing runs and unlocking achievements along the way giving you an insentive to beat the unbeatable. This game is for the people who are prepared to get frustrated, pull out their hair, quit the game and then come back to it the next day with a fresh mindset and with the hunger to get further each time, learning more and more with every click of the start button. I have heard many times that the game is unfair and too one sided, let me just say You is mad
date: cus You is bad".\n\nI think its more than fair to say a large proportion of the game will come down to luck and finding either exactly what you need at a shop/encounter or you finding useless items not worth the jump taken to get there. For me this adds to the challenge and gives the game more depth
recommended: without it there would be less need for exploration of a star system and a lack of increasing intensity that you might not find a shop before you run out of fuel or needed items. If you were able to jump to a shop and have the full range of items from the game to choose from then this game would be a breeze. If you land at a shop and find the useless crap we all dread to stumble upon after jumping strategicly to the only shop visible then move on! Discover another shop. There are multiple shops per star system it just takes planning and insightful purchases to easily discover most of the map before moving on. However this game is not all based on random blind luck and any one that tells you so well...... I question their inteligence and so should you. This game has been built for replayability and the challenge that comes with it. Of course if you decide to send you crew down to a planet to help survivors there is a good chance they will not come back..... so dont!. If you rescue a crazy man from a pod or planet DONT take him on board. "If you avoid risky encounters then you survive risky encounters". That is a phrase that should be forced upon people when they start up the game.\n\nAs for the lack of content....... well I have to say that I haven't encountered this as a problem. I understand the feeling of getting to the final boss with an almost perfect ship
hoursPlayed: defeating him and not being able to help but want to carry on. Surely this in its self proves that the game has been entertaining though. In my eyes if I come to the end of a movie and I am left wanting more then surely that movie was a success and made me feel exactly how it should have. Going back to pure content

reviewText:
Cute, little rogue-like spaceship sim game.

The role is simple, fly on the other side of galaxy map to warn your fleet about upcoming rebel invasion and it's weaknesses.
Flying through 8 sectors, each containing many systems you have to hold on and maintain many encounters of enemies, random events and threats by space phenomena.

Given yourself the ship of your choice, you can upgrade and set pretty much anything giving you so large options of Micromanagement. From manning the ship systems with your crew to weapons, shields, drones and ship's energy power distribution. During combats you can also pause the game any moment, thinking and planning your moves ahead which comes handy in most of the chaotic situations.

Destroying enemy ships provides you with gear and scrap for which you can buy better stuff in Stores scattered over the space. Not only by simply destroying enemy ships you get victorious, you can also either disable their life support systems or send in the Assault team both resulting in killing the enemy crew, giving you much more rewards.

Getting through the game makes you unlock more new ships or their new weapon/system/crew layouts after successfully completing achievements with each of them. Can you save yourself while getting through the space with Rebel fleet chasing your tail making you not to stop for long in each sector?

Personally I am not much of a fan of Rogue like games but this one can be hard, fun and still mannageable at once.

TL;DR -> 8,5/10, Would buy again.

reviewText:
One moment your ship is fine the next you have a populated force scanning your crew and you find out that your crew member has commited villany crimes.

You will be traveling through space when you stumble across a space pirate who attacks and then surrenders,in return gives you a slave.

You can have robots to protect your ship or drones too.You can hire aliens to be part of your crew.

You could come too close to a solar flare and your ship starts to burn.Your oxygen room is hit by a laser and then your crew starts to choke.

You get a pirate asking you to hand over you crew or they will destroy you.

You can choose multiple ships and customize your crew.You can have different ship layouts.

Everytime you start a new adventure the place you visit in randomly generated so it is always new.

There is so much to do and so much to unlock and it will take ages to explore the adventures you will endure with Faster Than Light.I couldn't recommend enough as even I was scared it was not worth my money and that I could find a better game for my moneys worth.

If you like Star Wars,Star Trek,Mass Effect,Halo,Space,Planets,Aliens,Robots,Drones,Space Pirates,Space Ships,Random events,Lots of content,Awesome music,Good Mods,Powerful weapons and anything Sci-fi or anything like I just said then you owe it to yourself to buy this brilliant game.

10/10

reviewText:
This is a long review, so if you just want a quick summary of this game please skip to Results and read from there.

Subset Games makes an amazingly epic choose your own adventure space combat game.

Similar to a storybook FTL: Faster than Light allows you to choose destinations to approach with each location giving you a dialogue with options explaining events at the chosen location.

Campaign:
You play as a federation ship whose mission is to fly throughout eight space sectors in order to deliver vital information to federation fleet. The rebels are taking over the entire space system and you must fight tooth and nail to achieve victory. In each system you will run across a variety of different individuals from Pirates, Aliens, Bandits, Slavers, Smugglers, Merchants, and Humanitarians who all trove the galaxy. As the game progresses you build a ship, stock it with a crew, maintain base systems, and complete quests. The end of the game is a three part battle with an monstrous flagship which unless equip can be near impossible. FTL: Faster Than Light is a fun game that’s highly addictive and keeps you wanting to come back for more. The combat is gripping, the constant threat of an oncoming fleet of rebels keeps you moving, and the amazing scenarios make you want not. This fantastic game although great has its limitations and may not be for everyone. FTL is a hard game, even on the easiest difficulty it is no cakewalk. Advanced Edition Content adds new items to the game adding more complexity and difficulty to an already hard enough situation.

Gameplay:
The game plays rather smoothly. Each “jump” you do acts as a turn and allows for the rebel fleet to progress further through a sector of the galaxy. If you and the rebel fleet cross paths you enter a battle, which if you play your cards right you can escape or even win. There is a steep learners curve, but once you’ve figured out the general game mechanics FTL plays rather easily. You have the ability to pause the game during any battle in order to maneuver troops and properly decide how to place your shots. The game asks you scenarios and the result of them are entirely dumb luck, so be prepared to take chances. For example you may end up trying to communicate with an alien race and get great rewards or an equal possibility is that crew member may die. The battles can be very intense and there can be situations where you are perfectly equip and the luck of where an asteroid lands can completely change a guaranteed victory into a struggling brawl.

Difficulty:
This game has a lot of luck involved, so about half of the difficulty in this game is the luck and not the skill. Although this may seem to make the game look bad, it offers variability that many games do not. You will be on your toes not just because of the difficulty from the actual skill of the game, but also because anything can happen and in one foul swoop you’re ship and crew will be gone. If you want examples of why please comment as I have many examples where I have lost because of luck, but don’t worry I also have lots of why I have lost because of skill as well haha.

Hints:
1) Make sure you visit every possible point you can for each sector, fight off as many enemies as possible because every piece of scrap matters and you will need it all if you want to win.
2) Make sure you take advantage of your crew, the longer they man a station the more efficient they become at it.
3) It’s a good idea to have a crew member in every station that placing one in can provide a benefit to your ship.
4) The mind control device is probably one of the best ways to distract an enemy ship’s crew and help easily destroy the ships interior.
5) The enemy ships will always have weapons of equal charge time charged before you.
6) The best way to give yourself first shot advantage is the cloaking field, it is worth saving up for.
7) The Flagship has four guns, the best way to defeat it is to defeat the crewmember manning each gun.
8) In my opinion the best way to defeat the flagship is with as many flak cannons as you can get (and possibly a missle that teleports itself), the cloaking field, and mind control. This will allow you to control a crew member of the enemy ship, go invisible while you recharge your weapons, and garantee you hit through the flagships shields.
9) If you kill every person in the flagship an AI takes over which is a lot harder than if you just leave someone alive (try and kill everyone except one person that way you can use them with your mind control).

Results:
FTL is an amazing game, but it’s not for everyone. The graphics are not top of the line and the difficulty level is high enough to make you want to strangle someone. FTL offers so fantastic fights that really keep you on the edge of your seat coupled with fantastic variety making each play through feel like a new game. If you quit a game it will create a save, but you can only load that save one time meaning that if you die you must start over. I recommend FTL, and would even recommend paying full price, but if get this on a sale it is definitely a steam-steal.

Pros:
+Amazing depth and variety throughout the campaign
+Option to play with or without advanced edition content
+Loads of different weapons to choose from
+Quests and distress signals to keep you invested in each sector
+Choose your own path so you can preemptively target your gameplay.
+Epic space battles that focus on managing both the interior and exterior of a ship.
+Many different ship designs, but good luck getting them unless you plan to invest several hundred hours into this game.
+Different sector types that offer different combat and elements.

Cons:
-The choice results are random, there are a lot of take your chance situations.
-The battles can be decided by dumb luck rather than skill.
-The final boss battle (the flagship) is rediculously difficult. [for advice check the hints section]
-FTL has a lack of resolution settings and in windowed mode it looks like is barely 1024x768 and does not allow you to make it larger.

reviewText:
FTL (Personally known by me as, 'For The Loss') is a fantastic, yet brutal spaceship management simulator kind of game.
Now, let me get this out of the way first:

Do NOT let the graphics or any gameplay videos you may have watched put you off or mislead you.

It may seem boring, but I assure you, it is anything but boring! I would definitely put it up there with all of the most intense and nail-biting anxiety kind of games out there. Things will go wrong, and it will go, REALLY wrong. I won't spoil some of the awesome, random text based adventure type events you can get thrown into - many which require interesting decisions that could be risky or extremely rewarding. But I will tell you this: AVOID ALL GIANT ALIEN SPIDERS AT ALL COSTS.

Another aspect I like about the game is that it forces you to make many morally questioning decisions - and not have the added consequence of facing penalties or filling some kind of renegade-like bar. You could show mercy on a surrendering pirate for a bribe, or just blow it to smitherines and scrounge the extra scrap from their ship. That being a very basic example of what FTL has to offer. The galaxy is in chaos, and there won't be a Jiminy Cricket on your shoulders or any form of Devil's Advocate telling you what to do.

While the game can be brutal at times, I love how most of the time, every time you fail and your ship explodes, it is due to you being that little bit extra over-confident. By not visiting every star system possible, by running out of fuel, by not having a good variety of crew member races or even just not upgrading your shields enough etc. Whilst some deaths may be a little unfair (with the rare events of random spawns of four enemy mantises instantly aboard your ship), most are justified.  You will fail a lot; it's taken me around 30 hours to fully complete one game on just EASY difficulty. A full game should only take around 2 hours to complete in the first place. I still must attempt to complete the game on Medium and Hard difficulty, unlock all the other ships in the game, unlock all the achievements, and even try out the recently added Advanced Edition with tons of new content. Unlike some short indie games, FTL has tons of replayability value, while still holding it's unique charm and memorable moments.

Now, I don't think I can be bothered talking about everything, as this review is already dragging on, and I'd like you to find out many of the other surprises yourself if you get the game. But I'll just talk about the sound design now, which in my opinion, is AWESOME.

There's something strangely satisfying about charging up your lasers, and unleashing hell on a hostile ship. The pew pews could not be better, or any more visually satisfying, unless it was perhaps given a blockbuster budget and directed by Michael Bay, I suppose. The music can also really immerse you into the game, especially in the moments of exploring the systems peacefully, with some really catchy songs thrown in there. I've heard some complaints about the combat music being a bit bland, but I personally quite liked that too. Overall, Kudos soundtrack guy! :D (Ben Prunty).

TL:DR: If you love Star Wars/Star Trex/Firefly/Cowboy Bebop/Any space sci-fi series, and always wanted to experience the kind of hardships of running a spaceship and crew successfully through the galaxy. Buy this game.

If you enjoy challenging games, which the industry has a huge lack of these days. Buy this game.

If this game happens to be on sale. BUY THIS GAME.

I'd give it a solid 9.5/10. :)

reviewText:
I have owned this game since 2012 and keep coming back. The replayability of this little gem is beyond belief!
I love it so much I even bought the web-based Humblebundle version so I could play it on my phone

You control a space ship and it's crew, each playthrough you fly through a unique procedurally generated universe fighting pirates & invaders, helping refugees and completing quests. All the while upgrading your ship and expanding your crew

Equip your ship with better shields and weapons, upgrade your facilities, cargo calpabilities, and just about everything else along your journey

All just to meet your ultimate demise at the hands of a vastly superior or often just very lucky foe and then roll a new game and start from scratch

A masterpiece!

10/10

reviewText:
Human mind can barely understand how something so simple as FTL can still be so ingredibly complex and fun. If you are a fan of science fiction series like Star trek: TNG, Babylon 5, Stargate, etc. You will be addicted right away. You really feel like being a captain of your ship and you have to make decisions with the knowledge you have at a time. Things can really turn upside down just after the next FTL-jump.

You can't describe the intense you got while playing this game.Tough sacrifices and narrow escapes of certain death are always part of your journey as you carry on the mission. Worthy experience to anyone who is able to learn from mistakes and won't give up easily.

10 - Perfect game
9 - Excelent game, best of the genre8 - Good game, worth your time
7 - Average game, nothing really special
6 - Bad game, avoid
5 - Painful to play, completely waste of time
4 - Failed game, unpayable

reviewText: I get bored with games very easily. However, I have not gotten bored with this one yet. There are so many ships to unlock, achievements to be gotten, and best of all, the game changes each time you play. Many people say this game relies on luck, and it does, but I like that. It means that there is no strategy that is guaranteed to work each time, which makes it harder, but a lot more fun. This is not a game you play twice and win. You can play hundreds of times and might still not win, but it's not the winning that's fun. It's finding that perfect weapon for your build, that teleporter just when you need it, unlocking a new ship. I could go on and on. This is a very hard game, and it's very unforgiving, but winning isn't what makes this game fun. Its the journey.

reviewText:
If you don't want to read you can watch the video review which basically says the same.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v2ZRO6Lbnqc&nohtml5=False

Faster Than Light is a 2D roguelike game set in space, the roguelike genre has been crawling its way back into the spotlight, however it's not common to be set in such environment.

You're part of the Galactic Federation that assigned you critical information that you must deliver eight sectors away, to do so you're given a spaceship that you must upgrade and fill with crew... All this, while being chased by the Rebel force, nice setup.

Faster Than Light relies heavily in random generated encounters since every time you warp to a location, you have hundreds of possible encounters with multiple outcomes, however this outcomes are sometime random as well, since the answer you gave on one playthrough might not have the same outcome on the next one. Often enough you'll feel the game cheated on you and that the result wasn't fair, however this also makes the game alive and filled with high risk high reward situations.

The combat system is pretty straight forward, when your weapons are loaded you can fire, when your enemy has their weapons loaded they can fire back, however you can assign crew members to certain stations, for example to the shield station which will make the shields recharge faster or to the engine station that will help you dodge incoming fire. Even though encounters are important you also have to make decisions inside your ship by choosing your crew members which unlock special encounters solutions but also come with their pros and cons. You'll have a whole bunch to choose from the Humans, the Engi, the Mantis, the Rockmen, the Zoltan, the Slugs, The Crystal and finally the Lanius.

The art of this game really stands out mainly the soundtrack that is masterfully done setting the perfect atmosphere for a game that leaves you on the edge of your chair, you'll know what I'm talking about once everythings starts going wrong and your entire ship is set ablaze or when you find yourself drifting  in space with no fuel, waiting for friend or foe to approach you with a helping hand or a loaded cannon.

However not everythings perfect, even though the game is filled with Quests and Encounters they somewhat lose their essence after some playthroughs when you start seeing them repeat too often with outcomes that you are now aware and can predict most of the time. Also the difficulty even on the easiest setting might be too hard for the casual gamers, which might put some people off the game after some tries.


+ Diferent Strategies and Aproaches
+ Great Variety of Items and Races
+ Amazing Soundtrack

- Encounters get repetitive after a while

88% Cool Game!

Join my Steam Group page for more reviews: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/jereviews

reviewText:
FTL is a 2D action strategy set in space, The objective of the game is to build up your ship with better defenses, weapons, systems, crew etc. . .   Making your way through the increasingly difficult levels until you defeat the final boss.

The game has lots of content and replayability unlocking new ships for new playthroughs. Every time you play the game it is different from the last, encounters are random and the game map" changes each time.

Music in this game is awsome the soundtrack is well made and fits the atmosphere of the game perfectly.

Graphics are basic 2D but the art style is good so don't let it put you off.

reviewText: Questo FTL - Faster Than Light (grazie al cielo che il titolo è in inglese, il corrispettivo termine italiano è Velocità Superluminare, e nessuno vuole giocare a qualcosa con un nome così brutto), rinchiude tutto ciò che un RogueLike dovrebbe avere, con la differenza che al posto del nostro classico eroe solitario questa volta dovremo portare la nostra astronave alla fine dell'universo! La storia è semplicissima, ma tanto non serve a nessuno conoscerla: abbiamo rubato dei preziosissimi piani segreti e dobbiamo portarli in salvo alla fine dell'universo, mentre tutta la flotta galattica di non ricordo quale fazione ci starà alle calcagna, avanzando a rastrelliera, galassia dopo galassia, per trovarci e sterminarci. L'universo, in questo gioco, è rappresentato come una fila di galassie da esplorare (otto, per la precisione), ognuna composta da un buon numero di punti di interesse" tra cui possiamo trovare richieste di aiuto
hoursPlayed: navi pirata pronti a tenderci una trappola e utilissimi negozi spaziali (oltre a tanti eventi più o meno unici
voteText: a cui possiamo reagire in diversi modi a seconda del nostro equipaggiamento e della composizione della nostra ciurma). Oltre all'ansia di aver alle spalle tutta l'armata galattica

reviewText: Random generation of the maps allow for nearly infite replayability. To me this is what games should be, solid game mechanics on top of flexible levels allowing you to play what makes the game fun over and over. At times you can feel invincible tearing through easy encouters, only to make a bad warp and have your game crumble in front of you. Other times you'll feel like you're barely outrunning the rebel menace and finding salvation through a lucky jump to some great ship parts. This game is not for people who like to know what is always coming, but I personally love how it always leaves me questioning if I am making the right decision.\nBuy this game if you like strategic thinking in an uncertain world.
voteText: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This cruel rougelike will test you to your very limits. A small mistake will cost you big here, although there are many things you cannot control. A lot of this game has RNG aspects, causing some very frustrating situations (I'm looking at you, giant alien spiders!). This game is insanely difficult, and there is no doubt that all players have raged at some point. There are many difficult situations to be made at times. An example of this is what to spend your precious scrap on. A single mistake can cost you big time, and can often result in the death of a crewmember or a loss entirely.

In spite of this, this game is a blast to play, and it is very satisfying to hear the sound of a hull breach in an enemy ship or to destroy a ship. There are many different alien races that all have different advantages and disadvantages to them. For example, Rockmen have increased health but move much more slowly. There are many different ships that can be unlocked, with entirely different play styles.

I have passed 20 hours of playtime at the time of writing, yet I've barely scratched the surface of this outstanding game. Unless you get angry REALLY easily, it would be idiotic not to pick up this game NOW.

reviewText:
Work in Progress
This review is incomplete. I will update/finish it when I find the time.

This is currently my favorite offline game. Anytime my usual addictions are unavailable, I always head straight for FTL and tackle another playthrough. This game is easily worth the $10 USD price tag, if not more. The recent expansion pack only adds to this value, and I almost feel guilty for not paying for so much content. It could have easily been a $5 DLC.

FTL is a roguelite space simulation game developed by Subset Games. It features perma-death, realtime strategy with the ability to pause and give orders, randomized level design, and nearly endless replay value.

Starting off with the tutorial, you'll get a quick briefing of the plot and objective, followed by a rundown of the UI. After jumping to the next location, you'll find your first battle which offers some helpful tips like using missiles to take out enemy shield systems. After combat, upgrade your ships reactor and weapon system and you're all set. The whole tutorial takes about 5 minutes. If you can't be bothered with 5 minutes, skip it. You can mouse-over just about everything for detailed tooltips at any point in the game.

My biggest, and only notable, gripe with this game is that it doesn't support Steam Achievements. I find this very odd since it has it's own in-game achievements not recognized by Steam.
voteText: 16 of 28 people (57%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Sigh...I...cannot in good faith recommend this game.  Not to everyone.  Is it bad?  Hell no.  This game is remarkably polished in a number of aspects.  The problem is, the game isn't very fun.  At least not in the long run.  When you start off, you will be full of wonder, piloting your starship into unknown realms, trying to save the your allies from the rebels!  Then you'll die, lose everything and have to start over again.  This pattern will repeat for about 20 times before you become super frustrated and give up on the game.

Let me reiterate...FTL is not a bad game.  It is damn good.  However, it fails in one crucial way.  It does not give you a feeling of incremental progress.  Some may like the challenge that that brings, but for a rogue-like to be worth your time these days, with so many other rogue-likes out there, it needs to make your time meaningful.  FTL is a time waster...it will kill you over and over again and it will be due to randomness, not to any fault of your own.  And seldom ever will the game change or improve.  Of the over 10 ships to unlock, I got...four.  After many failed attempts.  By accident.  Each death was just as frustratingly stupid and unavoidable as the last.

If you like that, fine, have at it, the game's mechanics are solid, but...FTL just wastes my time.  And I cannot recommend it on those merits alone.

reviewText: A new story everytime, FTL offers simple, yet deceptively deep gameplay. One of the few starship simulators out there that let you command the crew inside of a ship and the ship itself, rather than either one or the other. Great for fans of sci-fi and strategy alike.

reviewText: FTL: Faster Than Light is a beauty. With an aura of adventure and strategy so other games cannot have, this is one of my favorite games. The game's balancing is excellent. The unlockable ships are not more powerful than the starter ship; it all depends on skill and play strategies. This game can weed out the unfit by having them rage quit because of the game's difficulty, but those who are in that crowd-myself included- can enter the Easy Mode which is less of a challenge. The permadeath experience causes you to mourn a crewmember's loss in two ways more than most games; Not only do you care about them, like in most games, but you also rebuke yourself for your foolishness if it is your fault and begin freaking out a bit when your ship starts failing. And the fealing of panic is spot-on. If there's a hull breach, then another, then six fires, you start panicking. This leads me to the excellent feature of the pause button. You can plan your attacks, repairs, and defenses. For those players who want more of a hardcore experience, you can test your skills without a pause button. The risks of death in random events are high, making you want to take part in less; this is a good feature as well. The overall experience of the game makes this incredible. The satisfaction of unlocking a new ship is incredible. The difficulty of a fire or a hull breach in your ship makes the experience even better. The difficulty and yet rewards in boarding parties is amazing as well. Everything in this game can be decided by a single variable in anything. If you have enemy boarders on your Engi ship, you're a bit screwed, but if the enemy has Human crew and you attack them with the Mantis, there is a lot less struggle. This game... Is incredible.

reviewText:
That's exactly the game I've been looking for.

You select a spaceship and go into the deepest space. You manage the crew and fight with other spaceships. You'll be able to upgrade different systems like shields, engine, oxygen, weapons etc. Also there're subsystems like doors, sensors. For example, you can upgrade your doors so fire from one room won't get into another. That's really helpful, because there'll be a lot of explosions which will cause fire.

While playing you gotta care about fuel and the condition of your spacecraft. If it's broken - the game ends.

The best idea about this game for me is that YOU control every system and every single person from your crew you have on board. It's much more interesting this way.

I strongly recommend to you buy this game if you prefer to think and not thoughtlessly shoot everything that comes in your sight. Buy it anyway.

10/10!

reviewText:
ストラテジー　ローグライク
日本語化可能

一つの宇宙船を管理し、敵に追われながら宇宙を進むゲーム。
難易度は高く、イージーで他のゲームの普通ぐらいの難易度がある。

とにかくイベントが多い。
傾向はあるが、基本的に発生するイベントはランダムなので何回やり直しても違う旅路になる。

ただランダム性が高いわりに発生するイベントは鬼畜なものが多い(運が悪いだけかも)。
そのため場合によっては簡単に船が沈む。
ゲームオーバーになる要因がたくさんあるのが見所かも？

やりごたいのあるローグライク系のストラテジーがやりたい人におすすめ
スタートレックとか古典的な宇宙SFが好きな人にもおすすめ
それ系の小ネタやオマージュが随所に存在している。

※日本語化の注意。
Mod Managerは旧バージョン(1.6を推奨)を使用すること。
最新の1.7だとwindowsではpythonを正常に認識しないので起動できない。

reviewText:
During the weekend of PAX 2012 I got drunk and flew an RC helicopter into a friend's monitor, scratching the everloving ♥♥♥♥ out of it. I've since replaced that monitor at my own expense, but gained a memorable story and a threat I can live up to.

When my friend Carl recommended FTL, I was incredibly skeptical. So skeptical, in fact, that I threatened to fly a helicopter into his stupid face. He understood the risks and held his conviction that this game is worth the $10. It was $9 at the time, but whatever, sue me over a dollar, I'll fly a helicopter into you and your lawyer.

Six hours into this game and it's now safe to say Carl's stupid face will not greet my four rotary blades of destruction. This game is deceptively challenging and more importantly, deep. In my first four fledgeling hours, I was able to kill my crew and strand them in space without even trying. Now, I know how to keep them and my ship alive through all the randomized sectors and I have fun doing it.

After 24 hours, I defeated the Flagship. On easy. Damn I'm bad at this.

reviewText: Everyone knows about FTL in some form or fashion, its a household name by this point in time.  It is a 2D topdown stratagy game, and also a Roguelike game, that features permadeath and random chance.  No two play throughs are the same.  You also have the ability to unlock other ships of other races to try new tactics, each ship has its own uniquie challenge and twist to add to the game.  However sometimes the game screws you from the start with a bout of bad luck, to unlock more ships often requires absurdly good luck while your blindly jumping around trying to get everything you need.  It is most definatly both fun and keyboard snappingly frustrating.

reviewText: A fun top down, strategy game that has some RPG like elments to it. I haven't had so much fun with one game in a while. I was surprised taht it was such an amazing game. You'll spend countless hours trying to go through space warding off pirates, stop boarding parties and avoiding cosmic disasters. All the while trying to get to the Federation fleet to stop the Rebels, who are right behind you. FTL is a must if you like strategy or space games.

reviewText:
FTL Is an all around awesome game.
Simple, easy to lear gameplay mechanings, a really well designed and extremly thought out UI, combat system, and over-all game mechanincs make this one super easy to pick up, and tons of fun to really tweak and master.

The soundtrack is fantastic, the graphics are clean and look nice without having to have a gaming rig.  Not a big install, and overall the game seems well polished without any bugs.

Don't be afraid to play this game more than once, or more than a few dozen or hundred times.
And don't be afraid to love every single one of those runs, because they will all be different, and more importantly, they will all be fun. Each time you play again.

If this were in an arcade, it would be the game we all sink our quarters into a few rounds, every single time we go.

reviewText: FTL is an addictive, challenging game with fun RPG elements and surprisingly deep strategy.\n\nThe difficulty level has an amazing balance to it that most roguelike" games fail at - VERY tough at first while you learn the mechanics then quickly settles down to a sweet spot of constant tension and challenge but never frustration. Each playthrough becomes a narrative of highs and lows as crewmembers die
hoursPlayed: you get it repaired
voteText: you run from a nasty fight
helpfulPercent: you gain a new weapon
votesHelpful: etc etc until your ultimate success or demise.\n\nReplayability of the game is high with various ships to unlock
votesTotal: lots of weapons to find
votesFunny: different strategies to try out and of course the random generation of a new galaxy each run.\n\nThe game is 90+/100 for me
commentsCount: missing only steam achievements and leaderboards to take it higher. Highly recommend to any fan of strategy or RPG games.\n\n"

reviewText:
Brilliant rogue-like game. Combining 18 different ships (9 ships, but a second layout), randomally generated sectors and stores, along with tons of events which change every time you play plus augments (some exclusive to certain ships). It allows you to name your crew and ship....but don't...you'll get connected to them, then they'll be dismembered. The ships you fight can be defeated in a turn or can cleave your ship in half. The game forces you to think 'Do I need these shields upgraded' or 'Should I vent the broken oxygen supply when my ship's on fire along with several rooms and the Oxygen system and risk my crew'.

The music is amazing and over-all, I recommend buying FTL.

Music - 8/10. Enemies - 9/10. Randomization - 10/10. Customization - 10/10. Overall - 9: Glorious game.

reviewText: Best indie game I've ever played.  Crisp gameplay, well-thought out (and executed) mechanics - highly challenging, highly replayable, highly entertaining.  I've bought several copies for friends - it has been on sale quite frequently, so make sure you add it to your wishlist!\n\nAdded bonus: The newly-released DLC is free(!!!!).  In an time where big studios demand $15+ for content that expands the scope of the game less than 1%, this is a breath of fresh air.  Consider me a loyal Subset Games customer from here on out!

reviewText:
This game is sort of a roguelike set in space.  You start with a ship, some crew members and a mission, get to sector 8 and defeat the Rebels.  While it's graphics and mechanics are deceptively simple, there is a lot of subtle depth to the game.

You will die alot (like any good roguelike).  Luck certainly plays a role in your play through and you can't always count on a specific strategy.   Sometimes you'll just have to work with what is dealt to you.  There will be moments of complete rage and elation.

All in all, I have probably logged more hours into this game than most.  I've beat it on normal numerous times now.  But I still feel the urge to fire it up and roll the dice one more time.

EDIT:
The free Advanced Edition expansion just made the game even more awesome with even more strategies and toys available now.

reviewText: I have heard quite a lot about this game prior to getting it myself (thank you Humble Bundle!). However I was not prepared for such a mind-blowing experience. I was captivated for over 20 hours, leaving the screen only to pee or grab something to bite. And something like that did not happen to me for a LOOOONG time. But you may ask what is the game about. Basically you get a space ship, crew and some weapons to start with. From then you write the story yourself. Do you feel like a badass? Name your captain Mal Reynolds and fly your Serenity through the space to warn the Federation about the Rebel fleet attack (oh wait, something is not right here) or maybe you want to fly your own Enterprise. Everything is up to you.\n\nBut first you need to get over the simplistic graphics. These are rather functional, but come with an advantage of leaving a lot up to your own imagination, which may serve you better than anything drawn by A" class designers in the end. So what are you waiting for? Hurry up on your own boundless space adventure. It does not matter whether you prefer Cpt. Reynolds or Cpt. Kirk

reviewText:
It's not often that a strategy game takes my interest, but when this turned up in a Humble Bundle (which I bought because of Bastion, Limbo and FEZ) it blew my mind away. I had heard of FTL of course and had seen it in the Steam Store, but it never received a second glance from me because the main image for FTL looks so boring! Just look at it for a second; about twenty orange ships moving lazily across a planet. There's no sign of speed or that they're going Faster Than Light, and it gives nothing away about what the game is all about.

Maybe that's a good thing, because the game is bloody brilliant! You are the controller of a nameable vessel and you have information about the rebel fleet that is rapidly persuing you. Your ship has to travel through each area, making special Faster Than Light jumps between special beacon nodes. When you arrive at a beacon an event will take place, such as a battle, a trade or negotiations, where you choose wheather you will attack the ship, try to hide or even bring an alien crewmember on board. During a battle there's lots to do, which means a lot of work around the ship for your crewmembers (also nameable, although you'll probably get sad when one you named after your friend snuffs it). There are shields, weapons, drones, medbays and a reactor to power them all.

The soundtrack is lovely, as with a lot of indie games. When you enter a battle, the music for the current galaxy gets more intense, and will have you whistling all day long.

The great thing about the gameplay is that it can be paused at any time, even in the middle of a battle, so you can plan your next move. This is a great little aspect of the game, because it makes you feel like everything's happening at once and you have to choose your compromise, because this game is HARD. There are times when you feel like a pro and times when you wish you hadn't provoked the enemy, or wish that you hadn't destroyed a ship while your crew were still on board. A standard game of FTL: Faster Than Light can take about an hour and a half, and no two plays are the same. Give it a go!
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
FTL is a game about managing the crew of your spaceship as you explore and fight your way through to the rebel flagship. Managing your available crew and resources such as fuel and scrap is an important gameplay element. Plan ahead so that you can make it to the next repair-station and re-stock on fuel, but at the same time taking the gamble to buy a powerful weapon or upgrading your ship might be more beneficial in the end, if you get that far that is.
The game is very difficult, and at first it will feel as if the games randomness screws you over repeatedly, but learn from your mistakes, and defating the final boss is a very rewarding experience.
There are multiple ways to bypass your enemies, some are strictly combat oriented while others are event based and you get a choice whether to attack or not. Combat is also fairly diverse with many different types of weapons systems such as lasers, drones or why not just straight up board the enemy ship, which earns you more resources and possibly crewmembers as well.

Multiple ships and crewmembers that all come with special abilities gives this game alot of replayability, though most of the ships have to be earned by finishing certain encounters that rely on alot of things happening in a certain order.

The soundtrack is diverse and it is nice how the music seamlessly switches from a calmer exploration to the more agressive combat music as you engage enemy ships.

The graphics style is also really nice, with a spirite based style of graphics that is very pleasing to look at.

All in all FTL is a nice experience, though you will probably be frustrated with it a few times as you get no repair stations and slowly die with that awesome weapon you found early.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: A very simple game with very simple graphics, yet very addictive! The strategy is extremely well balanced and the progress in succeeding in the game is constant. So, the pleasure is always renewed, the replay value is big and the potentials are vast. This is a magic game that is at the opposite of any gaming hypes but is tremendously well done. Bravo! Bravo! Bravo! One of the best games I've ever played in my 30 year gaming experience.

Basically you get a space ship, crew and some weapons to start with. From then you write the story yourself. Do you feel like a badass? Name your captain Mal Reynolds and fly your Serenity through the space to warn the Federation about the Rebel fleet attack (oh wait, something is not right here) or maybe you want to fly your own Enterprise. Everything is up to you.\n\nBut first you need to get over the simplistic graphics. These are rather functional, but come with an advantage of leaving a lot up to your own imagination, which may serve you better than anything drawn by A" class designers in the end. So what are you waiting for? Hurry up on your own boundless space adventure. It does not matter whether you prefer Cpt. Reynolds or Cpt. Kirk

reviewText:
This is one of the most unexpectedly wonderful games that I’ve encountered recently. It’s a rogue-like starship with a basic objective: destroy the rebel flagship and pick up as many supplies and resources on your way there as you can to help you do it.

The most wonderful part of this game is that you can control all of the nifty little features that a typical space ship game should have that never does. Example: There is a fire in your weapons room. You can order your crew out of the weapons room and into another one and then use the individual door controls to vent atmosphere out of the weapons room to snuff out the fire, close the doors, repressurize and then it’s business as normal. (same tactic also works for boarding parties). That’s just a tiny little feature, but it’s stuff like that which make it feel like it’s actually your ship and you have a range of options on how to deal with situations you run into. If you want extra power on your shields or engines or weapons or sensors or door controls, you can actually assign your crew there to enhance the system in a pinch or build their skills for significant aids for the big battle.

Missile, beams, burst lasers, hacking, boarding parties, mind control, drones and automated boarding bots, med bays, clone bays, mines, etc. etc. The game has a host of systems and every play is unique, not only based on what your starting ship is, but the things you will encounter and what things you will pick up and the crew you will find. There’s disorienting nebulae, ion pulse suns, solar flares, asteroid fields and more. You can choose where you want to go in order to scavenge supplies and try to delay the rebel fleet. Some strategies may be to your advantage, others may not. It’s up to you and RNGesus.

Probably the biggest thing to note about this game is that it’s short – like really short. It’s not meant to be a 125 hour campaign (hello Crusader Kings II), it’s meant to be an old fashioned evening board game. Consequently, it typically takes only 2-3 hours to do a playthrough, regardless of whether you win or lose. Personally, I think this works to the game’s advantage. Because you do get to remember your crew and what their skills are, the weapons you pick up, and a general attachment to your ship, but not overly so that you cannot stand losing it and won’t ever pick the game up again. You should feel good about how far you came and that you did well even if you lose and look forward to trying a different strategy next time or just rolling the dice again and seeing what you encounter next time. You will most likely get to see the rebel flagship on most playthroughs on most ships, and whether you win or lose at that point is up to your achievements. It’s far more fun just to get there.

I finish taking the enemy ship and beam my crew back but the teleporter room is on fire and my crew dies before I can get them out. They were still hurt from the fight before.....I still have my pilot on board so I open my external doors and vent out all the oxygen to get the fire out, Ok fire is out but I forget the fact that my pilot needs oxygen to live...and the oxygen generator is down.....Restart #114

Best Rogue like I have ever played. Buy this and create your own memories.

reviewText: If people say this game depends completely on luck, then they're wrong. It has a huge random aspect to it but normally there is a safe option which comes with experience, or at least some kit which will avert the one crew member or 5 hull point danger. For the first 5 or so runs it's all very frustrating, but I can whole-heartedly say this is balanced out by the enjoyment of it when you pass the learning curve. An easier mode would be beautiful, however. All in all I'd say it's worth the money - there are plenty of guides for how to collect the unlockables, beat the boss and generally how to manage your ship online and in the guides section. Random events are annoying when you haven't encountered them before enough to know all the outcomes, but that's half the fun - will you get 100 scrap or will your beloved Steve be eaten by giant spiders? And just because it'll usually be the latter, but unless you're going hardcore with the Vortex, other crew members will know how to steer the hyperdrive-capable vessel they've wound up in.

reviewText:
What is there to say about FTL other than it is an amazing game that can provide you hours of limitless fun. The wide range of weaponry allows for a variety of play styles and can keep speedrunners and explorers alike entertained.
The real gem is the games combat system which allows for on the fly tactical decision making that can impact the fate of your ship and her crew, all at the slip of misplaced energy bars.
The graphics of the game are charming, and allow for those with lower end computers to enjoy the same fun as people with more expensive rigs. While it may be a turn-off for some, the simplified blocky art style showcases the gritty and fearful nature of the game and what lies beyond the great expanse of space
Procedural generation makes it so that no 2 adventures are the same, however the same cannot be said about the specific encounters or battles as they will inevitably repeat themselves. This can become annoying over multiple playthroughs, but overall will not detract from the game as a whole.
In conclusion, I would reccomend this game to someone who has always wanted to be at the helm of their very own starship, or someone who just needs a casual breakaway from your everyday AAA-cookie cutter title.

Rating: 9/10

reviewText: The Pizza's getting cold, and you've got all this interstellar traffic to run through! Not a problem for the Faster-Than-Light pizza service! You take control of a pizza delivery cruiser on your way to the Federation base, but the rebellion doesn't want you to get tipped, and they're pulling out all the stops to make sure that the pizza arrives cold, or even not at all! Fight your way through the many star-systems in the galaxy to make sure the customer gets their Hot-N-Ready pizza, defeat vile Pizza-Stealing Rebels, Zoltan speed enforcement zones, Mantis drive-bys, Rock shakedowns, and even the dreaded Engy tollbooths!\n\nCan you make it within 30 minutes or less? Or will the Federation taste the coldness of defeat?

reviewText: FTL: Faster Than Light is an indie game where you control a space ship crew running from a rebel fleet, trying to upgrade your ship and make your way your home before it’s too late. I liked the role reversal of a typical sci-fi plot here. This time it’s the rebels who really have the upper hand. It is an interesting game, and after you get the gist of it, also really fun and engaging for a while. It’s not a very long game but it relays heavily on the replay value. I must have started this game closer to 20 times before finally beating it. I unlocked some new ship types and can see how some people might really enjoy those but for me the game had already given everything I cared about. The atmosphere is really good and there are a lot of cool things you can do in space. The game also really makes you think some strategies and how you want to spend your money etc. I would almost call this a more interesting version of Solitaire. Sometimes you get good cards and can play the game through. Sometimes you just crash and burn after a while. It’s good fun and a solid indie title.

reviewText:
With over 500 hours, this is, without question the greatest $2.50 that I have ever spent, and I bought it on a whim when people weere complaining about how difficult and challenging the game is. I would happily have paid $25. ^._.^

This is a game that lives up to its name - a game that is known for it's challenging and difficult rogue like scenario involving a ship trying to make it to it's destination to save the universe, with you choosing and influencing how you accomplish this goal. It also has quite possibly the greatest soundtrack I have ever had the pleasure of listening to for a game of it's calibre. ^._.^

With a vast variety of weapons and tactics, as well as endless encounters that for some reason, while limited, never seem to get old, this game is well worth the money. I cannnot reason why it may appeal to some like me more than others, but I must say, should you ever be unsure, wait for the game to go on sale at either a steam summer or winter sale and give it a go. You will not be dissapointed.

An amazing game, very underated and I only wish I could express properly just why I think it's so great. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND this game! Give it a go! Ask a friend if you can play it! And above all else, don't give up so easily! One of my top ten favourite games of all time, and easily goes up with (in my opinion) other great indie games like amnesia. A wonderful gaming experience!

reviewText:
Let me just start this review by saying that you can't go wrong with an indie game like this one.

Graphics
Every single one of these elements will not be altered by mods, I'll leave that for my mods segemnt towards the end of this review. The graphics of FTL are simple yet extravagent, the game itself is simple, the UI is easy to understand and learn, and the different backgrounds/planets and stars all have their unique characteristics and look absolutely lovely. This game is simplistic, so I can't really take points off of it for having simple textures, it's meant to be that way.

Gameplay
Okay so first off this is a difficult lil game to learn in it's own respects, you have to master the art of pressing the spacebar (pause) before and after every show you take, and every shot your opponent takes. If you don't, well you'll end up losing crew members (which some crew members could take the entire length of the adventure to level up, and a loss like that is devestating to your progress). The best tip I can give you is to prepare to press the number keys (for your weapon systems) and the spacebar (for pausing the game) quite often as that will help you plan your strategy of attack a lot easier than not doing so in the first place. Obviously, I didn't pay attention to the tips or numbers above every panel in the game so it took me a while to realize I could use hotkeys, which made the game a lot more difficult than it should've been for me when first starting to play.

Story
This game doesn't have much of a story, you're the captain of your own warship that gets sent on a mission to find a stronghold. Along the way you encounter ships and planets/asteroid fielde and even colonies that try to brutally murder you and your crew within mere seconds of jumping into orbit. Your objective is to get to the end, with a powerful crew, upgraded subsystems and the weaponry to destroy the final boss (which is really, really difficult if you're unprepared). Overall it's an adventurious lil game and very, very addicting. You'll be racing to speedrun and beat highscores for hours if you get lucky enough to find good weapons along your journey.

Mod Support
Finally right? This is one of the most amazing parts of FTL as literally every part of this game can be altered through modifications that the developers even asked the community to make. From the story, where you can make finite decisions, endless journies and even completely different campaigns and stories such as Infinite Space. To the graphic overhauls where you get new backgrounds and visual elements from mods like Better Backgrounds and Planets to a mod like Crew Diversity that allows you to have multiple crew members with different visual looks and personalities. Here's the list of all working mods at this very moment, I recommend starting off with Captain's Edition and seeing how you like it from there, as the base game was stupendous but the mods make it into a gem of an adventure. http://store.steampowered.com Go there for more information along with every mod your heart could desire.

Summary
So in total, I've spent countless hours on this game and on experiencing the diffrent ways of playing through it, although the Infinite Space mod has no real ending other than you either becoming so overpowered that you literally cannot die, or you dying within your first two sectors, it's still lovely. I'd recommend that you buy this game because it's an adventure, it's a simple pleasure and it's enjoyable yet addictive. For a cheap pricetag, I managed to snag it for $2 through a steam sale a few years back. Obviously worth it, since I put so many hours into it and so much time into this review. Go buy it, it's worth it. Overall, a solid 9/10 from my perspective, if you were able to learn the UI elements more simply (before the tutorial was introduced, because that's when I started playing. Yes, all the way back in 2013, I believe) and able to learn how to maneuver through combat, then I'd give it a perfect 10/10.

reviewText:
By far one of my most favourite games on here. This game combines tactics, luck and the Final Boss to challenge you and replay. Its replayability comes into play when youve lost and you realise you can just start again, no frustration required. This game takes you on a journey through 8 sectors where your quest is to gather materials and upgrade your ship in preparation of fighting the Rebel Flagship, and along the way you are plunged into problem solving situations for greater or less/unexpected rewards, achievements and new ship layouts.

The Advanced Edition Expansion has made the game even more greater than it already was (if that exists). The features included are things like new systems and subsystems , new weapons , new race, Type C ship layouts and even a hard" difficulty and other miscellaneous additions. This has added a new twist to the gameplay and a new reason for "fed up" players (somehow) to begin playing it again. But regular old FTL still remains with just the click of button.

£6.99 GBP / $9.99 USD / €9.99 / 249 rubles

Having played nearly/already 100 hours
date: for me its a must buy."

reviewText:
This is a game about little space dudes trying to save their space empire from the evil space rebels, only to find that they run out of missiles on some dumb automated scout who's shields are too tough for their burst laser II to get through. So then they're sitting there waiting for their FTL drive to charge so they can jump away, hoping that their own shields hold, when the automated scout gets a missile through and hits their cockpit. So now their FTL is delayed, and the cockpit is on fire, and the mantis that was piloting the ship is trying his darnedest to put out the fire that's slowly killing him (but you know that giant space mantis has a hard time holding a fire extinguisher, so he'll die before the fire goes out). So the guy at weapons control heads to the cockpit to help, but since he's a rock dude he takes 15 years to get there. And while he's on his way, the mantis has had to leave before being cooked, heading to the med bay.

So now the fire is spreading, entirely engulfing the cockpit and the hallway outside of it. The mantis, upon reaching the med bay, is surprised to find that it's not working because power has been routed from it to supply the weapons systems. So they reroute power to the med bay, taking it from the O2 supply. But don't worry, they'll bring that back up before everyone suffocates, hopefully.

The rock dude has finally made it to the cockpit and is stomping out the fire, when another missile hits the shield generator and the shields go offline. Right as the shields go down, a halberd beam rips across the ship, hitting mostly empty rooms, but causing the automated warning sirens to alert the crew that hull integrity is down to 50%. Immediately, the remaining crew abandon their posts and rush to the shield room to get them back online. All of a sudden, the internal view screens go dark as the sensors are knocked offline by another missile.

The crew is panicking now. The rock dude, having finally put out the fire, is starting repairs on the navigational systems (though the crew still wonders how a large humanoid rock man can fix a computer terminal by simply hitting it, but hey, whatever works). Repairs to the shields are around 50%, so they come partially online, stopping the halberd beam. The automated drone, knowing no sympathy (or any emotion for that fact), continues it's relentless assault. Missiles continue to hit the ship, some tearing holes in the hull, others starting more fires. The rock dude makes his final repairs and brings navigation back online. It's only got another minute or so before it resolves the jump trajectory, but the crew isn't sure if they have that long.

Another explosion and siren sounds, this time signaling hull integrity at 25%. The shields are now fully online, and the mantis is back at the helm. There seems to be a shred of hope after all. The rock dude heads off to the sensor room to figure that mess out. Explosions continue to rock the ship; another missile strike to the shields (bringing them back down), and another halberd beam across the weapons systems. No shields, no weapons, and the only human on the crew is pretty sure that if she sneezes the whole ship will break apart.

This is when the crew realizes that they never brought the O2 back online. They try to route power to it, but the O2 control was hit by a missile and is offline. And the room is on fire, along with a good portion of the rest of the ship. The crew will never know this though, because the sensors are still offline (the rock dude is sill on his way). No oxygen, an unrelenting missile barrage, and the heat from the out of control fire sap the rest of the hope from the crew. Will they make it?

Probably not. But one thing is certain; they'll try again. And again. And again. Each journey a new adventure, a new story to be told. And maybe they'll get through to the end, to warn their friends in the space empire about the impending doom they all face.

Or maybe they'll have all their doors open when the door control is hit by a missile and all the oxygen rushed into space. That'll happen at least once too.

reviewText: If you don't own this game, frankly, you're missing out. It's an incredibly satisfying experience, and I get hooked every time I start it up. Expect to lose. A lot. But don't feel bad about it; dying is half the fun in this game! You learn better strategies as you keep playing (and inevitably being blown to bits), and once you finally beat the final boss... you're just on top of the world. I'm not a big fan of games that rely on luck as much as this game does, but this game is too much fun for me to care. ...Or at least justify having to care. It constantly makes you think and it rewards clever thinking. Just about anyone can have fun with this game; it's well worth the investment, even at full price.

reviewText:
If there's a kind of game that I can't stand, those are the Rogue-like games. They're, most of the time, luck-based, and you need to brain, skills, and sometimes you don't even need hands to play them. Faster Than Light is one of those exceptions that put the others to shame. While I hate the others, I just can't bring myself to hate FTL, it shines were others fail miserably. Is it perfect, though? No. As usual, I'll start taking the bad stuff out of the way first:

The biggest problem beyond the others, is that it's still luck-based. Not AS luck-based as the others, I might add, but being lucky is required in a lot of situations. Let me explain: During the game, you can choose what to upgrade or install. That's great, giving the player freedom. What's not cool, is some of those expansions being kind of needed during the final battle, and not having them meaning the difference between a last-minute Game Over, and achieving Victory. One of those being the Cloak. Being invisible and getting insane Evasion for a few seconds is NEEEDED during the Final Battle, but in one of my playthroughs, I ran to shop to shop (were, if they sell Expansions, only 3 will be available), AND I DIDN'T FIND IT, IN NOONE OF THE 13 SHOPS I RAN INTO. YES, I COUNTED THEM, THAT'S HOW MUCH IT ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ME OFF. WHY!? BECAUSE THAT'S ALL I NEEDED TO BEAT THE GAME! It was a perfect oportunity, had the best Load-out, and only needed the Cloak. Well, f#ck you too, Luck-based gameplay!

The other main issue here, is the lenght of the game. Yes, you can replay the game a sh#t-load of times and it won't get old that soon, but that doesn't make it easier to understand why they made it so short. You can beat it in an hour, less if you're lucky. But hey, you won't make it there without luck, so expect to start from scratch over, and over, and over.

The last issue is a minor one, really. Everything is randomly generated, as I said, but because of that, you often end up in hilarious battles that make no sense, and you can beat them by just staring at the screen. An example, would be the Auto-Scout ships with no shields in Asteroid fields. Those ships will only stand a few hits, but without shields, the asteroids will hit it non-stop, and the battle will last arround 5 to 10 seconds. Other times, enemies try to board your ship, even though you're using a Lanius ship, and that there's NO OXYGEN ON YOUR SHIP, so they pretty much instantly choke to death inside in some pathetic attempt of stealing your sh#t.

Now, let's go to the good stuff. The gameplay is extremely well done, and without counting the IA and the Random generator doing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ crap, you'll have some serious fun being the tactical ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you desire to be.

Will you load your ship with missiles and just blow your way out of there? Will you mount it with more and bigger lasers than the Death Star? Will you use robots to do your dirty job while you other more interesting stuff? Will you just board them, kill them, and steal their crap? Or will you just ignore them all and run away? It's up to you, and there's room for strategy to be made, specially with the Expansions you can install. Some of them turn your ship invisible for a few seconds, making it impossible to hit, others let you mind-control one of them for a few seconds and turn it against them, others let you hack their ship's stuff, you get the idea.

Another big point in favor of the game, is the music. It has been done to perfection. It seriously fits the action, and it also changes really smoothly from ambient music to combat music. The sounds are also okay, but don't expect to hear any voices, since the game is done in a more Old-school" and "minimalistic" style. There's also A TON of references to films
recommended: related to space or not...But a ton of them are from Star Wars. See if you get them when you see them.\n\nSomething that you should take into account are the mods. This game already has a sh#t-load of mods out there

reviewText:
It's 2016 and you definitely could see let's plays and other reviews of this game, so I'll leave the boring details out.

This is the kind of game that makes you start it on a Sunday evening at 11 P.M. to play it for 15 minues. The thing is, 15 minutes later it's 7 A.M. and you're late to work.

The gameplay is fantastic and the replay value is nigh infinite.

The soundtrack is a masterpiece, it fits the game's theme fantastically and creates powerful mood of lonely space exploration. It's almost romantic.

The only problem I can think of is incorrect naming of difficulty levels. They're not Easy, Normal, Hard, but Hard, Very Hard and Almost Impossible respectively. You will rage quit a lot at first, but then you'll start loving the way it hurts.


tl;dr: I haven't enjoyed a game as much since my childhood.

Great game! :)

reviewText:
Games such as FTL: Faster Than Light have been few and far between.  A proper rougelike, you never know what will happen during a run, and short of a proper ship layout, some luck, and a high level of skill, you probably won't get far often.
However, like any good roguelike, FTL isn't about winning everytime.  Too many games nowadays have no consequence for death.  This is all well and good in some ways, but we need more games like this one to make us genuinely try.

As for the gameplay itself, I couldn't be more satisfied.  A mix of real-time and something like turn-based gameplay (you can pause the action at any time and set up what will happen next) give you the time to react to a situation as you see fit, but how you react and how it is timed is essential.  Will your weapon charge and fire, knocking out theirs before they can fire back; or should you aim instead at their shield room to make certain that your future volleys get through?  Will draining the oxygen from the engine room put out the fire before they are destroyed; or should you risk your men in the blazing room to put it out and keep that engine running?  Is that heavily guarded ship worth it, or should you sneak past?

Enjoy your runs in FTL.  My advice?  Avoid giant spiders.

reviewText:
FTL: Faster Than Light is a space tactical adventure game. Travel across a series of star systems, surviving friendly or deadly encounters along your way, upgrading your equipment and accomplishing various quests. But time runs short as you are pursued by the rebel fleet, and only by making it to the last system quickly enough do you stand any chance of saving the Federation.

Pros: This game has plenty of replayability. For each playthrough, you have series of systems to fly through, and in each case a selection of branching paths, making each playthrough different. There is a bunch of accomplishments that unlock alternative ship designs. You can select your crew, depending on your starting ship species, from people you save, make deal for slaves of hire people on space stations, and your crew will get experienced in whatever they are tasked at doing. You have a limited amount of upgrades you can add to your ship, making where you apply these upgrades a critical decision on the type and quantity of equipment you can have and use.

Cons: I've said it before, but retro graphics just aren't my thing, and I'll leave it at that. The game doesn't allow you enough time to explore as much as you'd like to, as time is always a factor and you just have so many warp points you can travel to before you're caught up by the enemy fleet. Rooms are all pre-assigned, so you can't chose where to install your systems when you upgrade your ship: there's a pre-determined room in which it goes no matter what your defense strategy in case of boarding may be.

Verdict: ★★★☆☆ - It's up to you

If you don't mind the graphics (or even enjoy them) and enjoy a simplified rogue-like challenge, this game may be for you. It's exactly what it's advertising to be, so if the game seems interesting to you, it probably will be.

—————————————————————————
This was just my opinion.

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) reviews.
