reviewText:
FTL Faster Than Light is a rogue-like with the added twist of being set in space and based around ship management. The gameplay involves you mainly micromanaging your spaceship and crew as you travel through a number of random encounters trying to reach the other side of the map so you can deliver a warning to your rebel headquarters and defeat the final boss.

FTL is a game that relies heavily on it's difficulty, being much shorter than your average rouge-like. You manage a number of fairly limited resources as you slowly improve your ship and crew. You gather fuel, missiles and money and hope for new and better weapons and drones as your crew members gain experience in whatever field they are working.

It is a well made game and one I'm happily recommending but it's also a game that has some rather annoying limitations.

Your ship has very little customization options which makes repeat playthroughs somewhat dull, an unusual trait for a rouge-like. Choosing a different ship often yields much the same gameplay as even though your starting position changes a little, the only real change longterm is the configuration of the various rooms on your ship.

Another problem is the relatively short campaign you will begin to take note of once you've learned the basics and only the unforgiving higher difficulty gives it any sort of longevity.

All in all FTL: Faster Than Light is a nice little game, but it is also a game that needs something more before I'll agree with the underdog hype that seems to be going around everywhere these days. Perhaps strong developer support and a growing modding community will one day make this into the game it could be but as it sits now it is nothing special.
voteText: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
It's Dungeons Of Dredmor and The Binding Of Isaac but  in space. Faster Than Light is a roguelike game, meaning that if you die, it's truly game over. There's no reloading savegames, checkpoints, anything. You have to start all over again, except for a few things (like new ships or layouts) that you'll unlock during your games.

The whole game is randomly created so you'll never play the same game twice. There's also a bit of micromanaging. Scrap the 'bit' part, in reality it's pretty important and you'll micromanage your crew in practically every battle. Your crew will have to repair important parts of your ship and setting them up correctly might make them reload your weapons faster, or recharge your shields faster. They'll even have to engage enemies in combat from time to time.

Killed enemies will give you resources to upgrade your ship and buy stuff in shops. Stuff you desperately need in order to advance. In fact, soms of us might never even be able to complete the game, considering the fact that things are entirely random and it's also based on lots of luck. But it will never stop you from quitting the game. It's always fun, no matter what happens to your ship. You'll keep telling yourself; 'just one more game'. And isn't that what a game's supposed to do?

FTL is a great game and anyone who gives it a try will absolutely learn to appreciate it. Maybe not instantly, but after a few games ? Absolutely !

[Rating: 87/100]

reviewText: People who think games like Dark Souls is hard have probably never played FTL before. This strategy game where you control a space-ship that is running away from the Rebel fleet in an attempt to save the galaxy is honestly one of the most difficult rouge-like's that I've ever played. There were so many times when I'd reach the final boss of the game with max health and soon find my ship completely destroyed in mere moments simply because they'd breach my defenses before I could even graze their ship. This unforgiving game only lets you have one life throughout the whole game, and finding that the game runs on the weirdest random number generator doesn't exactly make things a lot easier on the player. The different weapons and ships make this game a hell of a lot more interesting, as you constantly have to make changes to your every move throughout the entire game. One moment, you may be dominating a supply ship to the point where they try to flee; but they can't because you shot down their engines. The next, the exact same thing is happening to you. With the new Advanced Edition, the entire game pretty much was changed and rebalanced (Flak is the most OP weapon. Get as much as you can). This game deserves a 9/10, for it's only problem being that unlocking new ships is too vague for most people to get, and with it's weird random number generator it makes it nearly impossible to determine if this gameplay will get me a new ship to use"."

reviewText: I really have no idea why I enjoy getting blown up by rebels so much. reviewText:
Let me just start off by saying that I adore this game any other roguelike I currently own. It's a fantastic piece of work that almost seamlessly melds roguelike and strategy that's unforgiving in the hands of a novice but nontetheless rewarding and worth replaying constantly. It has the best soundtrack of any indie game I've played thus far, and making it a dynamic soundtrack with idle and battle versions definitely helped that. The writing is also interesting and clever, and definitely making it worth a try for any fan of sci-fi. Advanced Edition, the recent free expansion, expands upon the game's content by at least a third and adds yet another reason to get back at it.

Regardless, I've come to dread the end level. Strategy and luck seem to go out the window in favor of luck alone. Your only real hope at winning is having fully upgraded almost everything, and if you don't have the right weapons and/or equipment you cannot hope to last the three phases of the boss. The boss presents no surprise and beating it becomes pretty formulaic. The Advanced Edition upgrades help mix it up a little and make it just a little less mind-numbing, but it still puts a dent in an otherwise near-perfect title.

9.5/10

reviewText: You're just flying along, and things are looking pretty up for you. You just boug-uh, HIRED another sla... I MEAN CREW MEMBER and you have upgraded your shields. Then suddenly you get stuck in a plasma storm in the middle of a nebula. You get attacked by a pirate ship who have disabled your O2 dispenser with a hacking drone. As they board the ship you are able to shoot their drone bay and fix your o2, then you lock your crew in the medbay and depressurize the ship. Just as you are getting ready for a daring escape, a bolt of plasma hits your engines. As you enter the room, you see fire all over the place that you could not have seen before because your sensors don't work in nebulae. As fire consumes your crew members, the pirates shoot your pilot and leave your ship totally unmanned, just as a bolt of plasma destroy them as well.\n\nWelcome to FTL. Easy difficulty.

reviewText: Are you tired of winning games? Do you love watching hours of thought and hard work get destroyed in an instant? Great! than FTL is the game for you! Become the pilot of a precariously fragile ship full of incompetent crew members on a journey through space chased by evil rebels and being attacked by pretty much everything. Enjoy an incredibly realistic, gritty sci-fi world full of death, poverty and slave labour all with the fitting backround of a lovable retro soundtrack. And if you complete the Herculean task of getting to the last level, prepare to have your hopes, dreams and two hours hard work shattered by a ridiculously powerful boss. This is a fantastic game with incredible soundtrack, tense gameplay and a lovable atmosphere, highly recommended.\n\nWARNING: This game is the most stressful thing on earth. If you are prone to heart trouble, suffer from a spastic colon or explosive diarrhea, or have ever felt stressed, then this game is not for you. Possible side effects include feelings of worthlessness, scurvy and crabs.

reviewText:
FTL: Faster Than Light is a game you have to see for yourself to understand. Not only is it a game, it's a spaceship simulator. Oxygen levels can fluctuate throughout the fight, and fires can erupt toasting your crew and burning more of the precious oxygen. How will you defeat your enemy? Will you light the oxygen room ablaze and suffocate them? Send boarders over and watch the chaos ensue? EMP their shields, and blow up the weapons? Better yet, how will you respond to that?

Will you send in your shields specialist to put out the fire, but leave your shields down? Will you lock the doors and cut of oxygen and suffocate the enemy? Will you be able to reroute your crew to get the shields back online?

Ironically, hilarious failures can be half the fun of the game. Whoops, forgot to close that door. Sorry pilot, didn't mean to suffocate you. Dang, forgot my boarders on the enemy ship!

The only flaws are the harsh learning curve, and the high difficulty can be offputting for some. Despite those minor nitpicks,  overall, I give it a 9/10.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Boy...

This is a tricky one.

I'm not going to NOT recommend it. It's a good game, that's for sure, and I don't regret buying it. I've only played 7 hours so far, but there's no doubt I'll sink in some more hours so... yeah, it's a good game.

But it's really not as marvellous and great and perfect as some reviews suggest. For one thing, this game does not have awesome random events". The game IS one gigantic random event. There's really nothing you can do that you are SURE will bring in positive or negative outcomes. This total lack of control feels refreshing at times
date: but it's more frustrating than anything else in my opinion. Some randomness is good
hoursPlayed: things get old pretty fast when everything works on a dice roll.\n\nOther than that
voteText: the game is pretty hard and unforgiving. Good change of pace

So don't get too attached to your crew... you'll see them die soon enough.\n\nSo... yeah. I like this game. But it's not the game of the century. It got so much praise that I guess I'm just a tad disappointed. Actually

reviewText: People who think games like Dark Souls is hard have probably never played FTL before. This strategy game where you control a space-ship that is running away from the Rebel fleet in an attempt to save the galaxy is honestly one of the most difficult rouge-like's that I've ever played. There were so many times when I'd reach the final boss of the game with max health and soon find my ship completely destroyed in mere moments simply because they'd breach my defenses before I could even graze their ship. This unforgiving game only lets you have one life throughout the whole game, and finding that the game runs on the weirdest random number generator doesn't exactly make things a lot easier on the player. The different weapons and ships make this game a hell of a lot more interesting, as you constantly have to make changes to your every move throughout the entire game. One moment, you may be dominating a supply ship to the point where they try to flee; but they can't because you shot down their engines. The next, the exact same thing is happening to you. With the new Advanced Edition, the entire game pretty much was changed and rebalanced (Flak is the most OP weapon. Get as much as you can). This game deserves a 9/10, for it's only problem being that unlocking new ships is too vague for most people to get, and with it's weird random number generator it makes it nearly impossible to determine if this gameplay will get me a new ship to use"."

reviewText: You're just flying along, and things are looking pretty up for you. You just boug-uh, HIRED another sla... I MEAN CREW MEMBER and you have upgraded your shields. Then suddenly you get stuck in a plasma storm in the middle of a nebula. You get attacked by a pirate ship who have disabled your O2 dispenser with a hacking drone. As they board the ship you are able to shoot their drone bay and fix your o2, then you lock your crew in the medbay and depressurize the ship. Just as you are getting ready for a daring escape, a bolt of plasma hits your engines. As you enter the room, you see fire all over the place that you could not have seen before because your sensors don't work in nebulae. As fire consumes your crew members, the pirates shoot your pilot and leave your ship totally unmanned, just as a bolt of plasma destroy them as well.\n\nWelcome to FTL. Easy difficulty.

reviewText:
REVIEW IS OUTDATED SINCE THE RELEASE OF THE ADVANCED EDITION
Main Menu
Tutorial
The game has a short 5-7 minute tutorial that explains the basics of the game. It does not explain everything such as Alien race benefits or ion beams, but it is enough to get you started on the game.

Stats
The game has a detailed stat screen that lets you know what ships you were piloting when you got your top five scores, as well as what difficulty setting you were playing. Smaller statistics are also shown such as Session records, Crew records, and Records over the course of all games including how many games you played and how many of them were victorious.

Achievements
Achievements are a part of statistics but I felt it should get its own section since some completionists care more about achievements then overall stats. Achievements are sorted into three different sections; General Progression, Going the distance, and Skill and Equipment feats. General Progression achievements are exactly as the name entails, achievements that you will get over time just by playing the game. Going the distance achievements are the ones you will be fussing over and replaying the games many time with certain restrictions to unlock, such as the No Redshirts Here" achievements that is unlocked by getting to sector 8 without losing a crew member (Any star Trek fans here?). Skill and Equipment feats are not as difficult as Going the distance achievements
date:
but you will still have to go out of your way to unlock them.

Options
There is a fair amount of video options.You can have your game windowed or in three different fullscrene modes
hoursPlayed: Stretch
voteText:
and Native (The native resolution for the game is 1280x720). Frame limit can be turned on and off although I suspect most people won't need this option since the game will likely not experience frame drops on most computers though this is a nice option to have nonetheless. You can turn dynamic background on or off. Colourblind mode is avaliable. For Audio options you have a sound volume slider and a music volume slider. Gameplay options let you rebind hotkeys if you wish.

Game
PreGame
At the start of the game you are allowed to rename your ship and crew
helpfulPercent: as well as choose what kind of ship you will pilot and the layout of the ship. You can see what is powered on your ship
votesHelpful: what species of crew members you get
votesTotal: what weapons you start with
votesFunny: what drones you control
commentsCount: and the augmentations preset into your ship. After you are happy with the ship you have chosen
column16: its layout
column17:
and its name you can choose your difficulty setting and start the game.

Difficulty Settings
This game has two difficulty settings. Easy Mode and Normal mode.
Easy Mode gives you more scrap and generates easier enemies. I would recommend this for a first time playthrough as it will still be a difficult game.
Normal Mode gives you the scrap you are intended to earn and generates tougher enemies then you would find in easy mode. Choosing Normal mode gives you a 25 percent bonus to your ingame score.

Story
"The data you carry is vital to the remaining federation fleet. You'll need supplies for the journey
column18:
so make sure to explore each sector before moving on to the next. But get to the exit before pursuing Rebel fleet can catch up!" Once you start off your journey you are greeted with a message box telling you exactly that as well as an ingame tip. Thats about it for the story you get from the game. It's really up to you to imagine your own story as you are given up to three different choices in certain random events. You have a basis for a story and are left to your imagination and gameplay for the rest.

Gameplay
There are three things you actually do in the game. Battle with hostile ships
column19: decide what to do for ingame events
column20:
and jump from location to location using your FTL Drive.

Game Map
you can choose connecting locations to move from as long as someone is piloting your ship. You cannot travel everywhere however because you have limited fuel that you must find in drops or buy from stores
column21: as well as worry about rebels catching up to you. Rebels get closer to you every time you jump from location to location. So you do not have to worry about them catching up to you due to a really long ship battle. There are Purple Nebula that slow down the rebel fleet thats chasing you when you jump through them. This does not come without cost however as your sensors are faulty and you can come across storms that limit your reactors power. When moving from one sector to the next the path is nto linier and has seperations. it is up to you to plan ahead and decide where to go as their are enemy controlled sectors
column23: and uncharted sectors (which are full of purple nebula. Civilian sectors have less hostilities
column24: Enemy Sectors are full of hostile ships as the name implies
column25:
and uncharted sectors are filled with purple nebula. Purple nebula in uncharted sectors do not give you the benefit of slowing down the rebel fleet as they are prepared for it. but you still have faulty sensors in these nebula.

Battle & Management
This is where you will spend most of your time in game. you can see the inside of your ship and its rooms (or the rooms your crew members are in only if you are in a purple Nebula or your sensors are broken). you can see what systems your enemy has nad where they are located. The Health of the Hull and their shields. You can power up your weapons and decide where they will target on the eneimies ship once ready to fire. you must be careful though as you have to constantly worry about the health of your systems and subsystems
column26: Battle enemies that teleported onto your ship
column27: keep your crewmembers at high health
column28:
and stop fires from ravaging your ship.
Systems and Subsystems
Systems are part of your ship that uses power from your reactor and subsystems provide their own power. your enemy can break these systems and subsystems so they no longer function. All systems and subsystems can be repaired by crew members and some systems even have added benefits if manned by a crewmember. Luckily the game lets you make decisions while paused so you do not have to constantly think in real time.
There are five main systems as well aso thers that you will find along the way. O2 is your oxygen supplies
column29: without oxygen your crewmembers die so this system neds to be functioning at all times and taken good care of. Engines Charge the FTL drive and powers your ships evasiveness. If someone mans the Engines the chance of dodging increases. Shields sustain your ships defenses
column30: if you shield system is manned your shields regenerate faster. MedBay systems heal your crewmembers as long as they are inside it. Weapons systems powers your weapons
column31: when manned weapons take less time to charge. The pilot subsystems must be manned to have any use
column32: it is used to evade during combat and jump from place to place. Sensors Enable view of your rooms and info on the enemy ship. Door subsystems let you open and close your doors. This allows you to take out fires by getting rid of oxygen in the room.\nUpgrades you can upgrade your systems subsystems and the amount of power in your reactor by spending scraps. Scraps are also used to buy items in shops so you must decide wisely if it is better to upgrade your ship or save the scraps to buy things such as weapons
column35:
and missles.
Crew
Your crew can consist of many different species with different traits. they get better at what systems they man over time.
Weapons
There are three types
column38: and beam. Missiles. Ion disrupts systems
column39: missile is powerfull but uses bought ammo
column40:
and beam does not require ammunition.

Soundtrack
The soundtrack from this game is amazing and gives you a sense of technology and the vastness of space."

reviewText: When I first played this game I must admit that it was not the file obtained from Steam that I was using.  However, after playing FTL for a while it has become one of my favourite games and the effort that has been put into creating this game is immense, so evident in fact that I bought the game because the developers simply deserve it.  Through an intoxicating mix of luck, strategy, and permadeath, this game presents players with countless scenarios and tools that can be used to progress throughout the galaxy.  The gameplay is incredible and very rogue-esque allowing for a modern incarnation of a game viewed as a classic by many.  The atmosphere generated by the universe of the game encourages great immersion and the soundtrack within FTL is one of the best I have ever heard.  Oh, and kudos to Subset Games for their uncommon chivalry in making a huge expansion pack for the game free to all players.  This sort of thing is not seen much anymore and it is a testament to just how much the developers care about the players who have invested in this amazing experience.  I am looking forward to any new adventure that Subset develops and I will without a doubt be playing it.  FTL is an incredible game that achieves everything it sets out to achieve and more, the game deserves nothing less than full marks and I recommend it to everyone.

reviewText:
This recommendation is a bit on the hesitant side, though I'll get to why later.

Anyway, First off, FTL: Faster than Light has a great soundtrack - and an interesting one at that. It tries to give a cinimatic feel without using orchestral instruments, and as a result it has a distinct sound. Bonus points are given for utilizing a leitmotief, and even more for making it subtle.

Graphically, there's not much to speak of. FTL has a very retro look, though kinda on the low-end of 16 bit or the high-end of 8 bit. The sprites are large and high-res, but there's no shading to speak of. The backgrounds feel a bit, well, stock, but look nice.

FTL's gameplay is easy to learn but takes a long time to master. You can get the hang of the game very quickly, but the difficulty is notable. It's not the hardest game I've played, but it's definately a challenge.

Which brings me to why I'm hesitant to recommend this game. Saying the game isn't the hardest game I've played" is not a very accurate way to judge difficulty
date: as I've played a few games that were so hard the average gamer would considder it torture (Exceed: Gun Bullet Children comes to mind). This game is definately out to get you (like any Roguelike) and is VERY obvious about it.\n\nStory-wise
recommended: FTL is pretty simple and a bit reminicent of one of the underlying plots of Star Wars
hoursPlayed: just in reverse. You've stolen the plans to the rebel flagship and are running from the rebel fleet. You must bring the plans to the federation HQ and then destroy the rebel flagship. There are a ton of side-quests and events that spice things up
voteText: and no playthrough is the same.\n\nOverall

reviewText: FTL: Faster Than Light is a masterfully crafted strategy game that is a love letter to any who find space adventure even the least bit compelling. And remember, dieing is part of the fun ;)

reviewText:
REVIEW IS OUTDATED SINCE THE RELEASE OF THE ADVANCED EDITION
Main Menu
Tutorial
The game has a short 5-7 minute tutorial that explains the basics of the game. It does not explain everything such as Alien race benefits or ion beams, but it is enough to get you started on the game.

Stats
The game has a detailed stat screen that lets you know what ships you were piloting when you got your top five scores, as well as what difficulty setting you were playing. Smaller statistics are also shown such as Session records, Crew records, and Records over the course of all games including how many games you played and how many of them were victorious.

Achievements
Achievements are a part of statistics but I felt it should get its own section since some completionists care more about achievements then overall stats. Achievements are sorted into three different sections; General Progression, Going the distance, and Skill and Equipment feats. General Progression achievements are exactly as the name entails, achievements that you will get over time just by playing the game. Going the distance achievements are the ones you will be fussing over and replaying the games many time with certain restrictions to unlock, such as the No Redshirts Here" achievements that is unlocked by getting to sector 8 without losing a crew member (Any star Trek fans here?). Skill and Equipment feats are not as difficult as Going the distance achievements
date:
but you will still have to go out of your way to unlock them.

Options
There is a fair amount of video options.You can have your game windowed or in three different fullscrene modes
hoursPlayed: Stretch
voteText:
and Native (The native resolution for the game is 1280x720). Frame limit can be turned on and off although I suspect most people won't need this option since the game will likely not experience frame drops on most computers though this is a nice option to have nonetheless. You can turn dynamic background on or off. Colourblind mode is avaliable. For Audio options you have a sound volume slider and a music volume slider. Gameplay options let you rebind hotkeys if you wish.

Game
PreGame
At the start of the game you are allowed to rename your ship and crew
helpfulPercent: as well as choose what kind of ship you will pilot and the layout of the ship. You can see what is powered on your ship
votesHelpful: what species of crew members you get
votesTotal: what weapons you start with
votesFunny: what drones you control
commentsCount: and the augmentations preset into your ship. After you are happy with the ship you have chosen
column16: its layout
column17:
and its name you can choose your difficulty setting and start the game.

Difficulty Settings
This game has two difficulty settings. Easy Mode and Normal mode.
Easy Mode gives you more scrap and generates easier enemies. I would recommend this for a first time playthrough as it will still be a difficult game.
Normal Mode gives you the scrap you are intended to earn and generates tougher enemies then you would find in easy mode. Choosing Normal mode gives you a 25 percent bonus to your ingame score.

Story
"The data you carry is vital to the remaining federation fleet. You'll need supplies for the journey
column18:
so make sure to explore each sector before moving on to the next. But get to the exit before pursuing Rebel fleet can catch up!" Once you start off your journey you are greeted with a message box telling you exactly that as well as an ingame tip. Thats about it for the story you get from the game. It's really up to you to imagine your own story as you are given up to three different choices in certain random events. You have a basis for a story and are left to your imagination and gameplay for the rest.

Gameplay
There are three things you actually do in the game. Battle with hostile ships
column19: decide what to do for ingame events
column20:
and jump from location to location using your FTL Drive.

Game Map
you can choose connecting locations to move from as long as someone is piloting your ship. You cannot travel everywhere however because you have limited fuel that you must find in drops or buy from stores
column21: as well as worry about rebels catching up to you. Rebels get closer to you every time you jump from location to location. So you do not have to worry about them catching up to you due to a really long ship battle. There are Purple Nebula that slow down the rebel fleet thats chasing you when you jump through them. This does not come without cost however as your sensors are faulty and you can come across storms that limit your reactors power. When moving from one sector to the next the path is nto linier and has seperations. it is up to you to plan ahead and decide where to go as their are enemy controlled sectors
column23: and uncharted sectors (which are full of purple nebula. Civilian sectors have less hostilities

and uncharted sectors are filled with purple nebula. Purple nebula in uncharted sectors do not give you the benefit of slowing down the rebel fleet as they are prepared for it. but you still have faulty sensors in these nebula.

Battle & Management
This is where you will spend most of your time in game. you can see the inside of your ship and its rooms (or the rooms your crew members are in only if you are in a purple Nebula or your sensors are broken). you can see what systems your enemy has nad where they are located. The Health of the Hull and their shields. Systems and Subsystems

All systems and subsystems can be repaired by crew members and some systems even have added benefits if manned by a crewmember. Luckily the game lets you make decisions while paused so you do not have to constantly think in real time.

reviewText: A rogue-like space mission in which you must deliver the last hope of a dying Federation in a marathon trip through several varied sectors. Your journey is restricted both by your limited fuel and the approaching Rebel fleet, so grinding isn't really an option. Each game should take around a half hour to an hour and a half and there is a nearly endless combination of weapons and modules to experiment with. Everything is controlled by very simple resources and upgrade trees, keeping the learning curve short. All great things which make for a great game. What I couldn't get over, and what drains a good portion of the fun out of this game for me, is just how random a rogue-like. It is nearly impossible to set a goal beyond survival and success. Various weapon combinations might excite you, but there is no guarantee you'll ever get a shot at testing them. The trade off here is, of course, that each playthrough is unique and if that's what you're looking for, FTL is perfect for you. However, if you look to strategy games for intense planning and not the fun a constant wrench in the works makes for, this might not be the game for you.

reviewText:
This game has been a surprise to me. Caught it in the Steam sale over Christmas and have to admit I didn't play it straight away. But casually loaded it up last week and have been hooked!

You start with a crew of 3, with a basic loadout of weapons, fuel and the ability to get some drones to assist you with tasks like ship repairs, intruders, among others. Your mission? KEEP MOVING! The rebels are chasing you from one sector to the next. On your journey you'll be encountering events such as pirates chasing down defenceless ships (do you help them? do you accept a pirate bribe to stay out of it?) and you can sell scrap you collect to upgrade your systems (buy additional crew members to help with unmanned systems, buy fuel, rockets, new weapons...). You'll never have enough scrap to outfit your ship completely so it's very important to make the right decision.

The random" element of the game is perhaps its best feature. No 2 games are the same
date: you can "jump" once and get an additional crew member
recommended: or you can jump and find yourself staring at a rebel ship wanting to shoot you to pieces.\n\n...and if you wanted more than something that was replayable
hoursPlayed: you've got a truly excellent soundtrack to listen to as you play that's atmospheric and draws you in.\n\nBest indie game I've played personally

reviewText: FTL is like one of those books where you get to make choices. You are a starship captain and it is your job to warn the Federation of the impending Rebel threat. You must decide which sectors to explore, while staying ahead of your enemy, and doing all the good things good starship captains do; like going tromping into a seemingly abandoned space station, all because of some faint life signs you can’t identify. Sometimes things will go great, like getting a new crew member or some much needed supplies, while other times ♥♥♥♥ hits the fan and everyone dies. Seeing your failed plans and bad decisions culminating in your voyage ending is soul crushing at first, but it's what makes FTL truly amazing.

reviewText:
I didn't think I would enjoy this game but I do. I'm hooked.

I thought that the fast-paced strategy would be chaotic and difficult to master. I was pleased to find out that you can pause the action at any moment and give orders, and that the mechanics are very simple and easy to understand. That doesn't mean that FTL is an easy game: plenty of choices and their consequences, as well as the random-generation make it quite the opposite. The game is never unfair to the player, giving many opportunities for upgrades and pacing the zones quite well.

Critical thought and planning ahead are as important as combat in FTL; saving some scrap" (the games spending and upgrading currency) could mean the difference between bribing a hostile pirate or having to engage in combat. Spending your "scrap" on ship upgrades could mean that you run out of fuel later in the game
date: or it could be the bump that saves your crew's lives.\n\nThe most aesthetically pleasing thing about FTL is the way it can be played with only a mouse. Pausing the action is bound to the middle mouse button
recommended: leaving your other hand free to grab a snack

reviewText:
8/10

This game has so many choices as well as so many different outcomes it causes for a totally different experience each play through. Faster Than Light is simply stunning (especially for being made by two people) and has a great gameplay idea. You play as the entire ship. Not just the captain. You play the role of each crew member, and the ship itself. When your vessel gets hit, it feels like your main character is taking damage. The game has multiple unlockable ships which cause for even more extended gameplay as each ship has it's own advantage as well as a disadvantage.

One thing this game is lacking in is it's modability. At least, stock modability. With the download of a few programs you're able to mod this game like no other. With mods including completely new ships, gameplay overhauls, improved graphics new enemies and so much more. FTL has a great player base as well. Full of fun, intelligent people. Updates are fairly often, and it's possible to get into the beta updates without much hassle. The game is mostly bug free, with the occasional glitch here and there. Another thing this game is lacking is multiplayer. Though, as of 07/12/13 (mm/dd/yy)  they are planning on adding it somehow..

Anywho, great game. Well worth the coin.

reviewText: This game is a very well polished extension of the Roguelike genre. You pick a ship from a number of different designs each with their strengths and weaknesses, and are sent forth through a series of randomly generated star systems in the hopes of becoming powerful enough to destroy the Federation Flagship. However, instead of training a single character as you progress through the game, you improve your entire ship, its subsystems, its weapons and the crew within it.\n\nThe game's charm lies within both its superb soundtrack which magnificently serves to highlight the action in the game, and its implementation of the game's different races and weapon types.

reviewText: FTL is a very intresting and complex game, it's quite basic in terms of weapons, ships, races, sectors, and graphics. It is a ship based game that takes place in a certain galaxy, and you, the captain need to guide your ship through 8 chalanging sectors, to save the galaxy. You have 9 completely different ships to chose from, each with their own different, races, layouts, weapons, designs, strategies, and of course types. There are currently 3 different layouts of each ship thus there are technicaly 29 different ships to chose from. Will you chose to go weapons heavy and obliverate anything that comes in your way,(limited by, luck.) or will you chose to methodicaly board and take out your enemies for better rewards the choice is usually yours. Luck is a huge factor in this game, but dont let luck control you! Be the bettter pilot and lead the Federation to victory!

reviewText: Your task for this game is simple, survive up until the end, then blow up the enemy ship saving the day (universe? galaxy?). reviewText:
Not sure how to classify FTL in terms of genre or playstyle, as it's pretty unique. It's a roguelike space simulator where you control your crew and ship as you race through various solar systems towards the end game. An individual game maybe lasts an hour or two or until you die (can be much sooner), but while winning is the goal, trying out new tactics and combinations of weapons is the fun part of the game.

You control a few crew members in a ship with various parts. You can assign a crewman to pilot the ship, one to control the ship's shields, and have a third crew rotate between manning the weapons systems and doing ship repairs. When you get into a fight, your ship takes localized damage that interferes with your ship's functions in every way. Thus, combat is a game of maintaining your ship and taking out the enemy as quickly as possible to minimize the mayhem they cause. Sometimes your ship will be boarded and you'll have to determine how to kill the enemy crew who are breaking stuff and attacking your own crew while trying to destroy an enemy ship that is likely still shooting you. The game has a million tactical possibilities every playthrough and is wildly popular.

It's cheap, and if you've got enough patience to play a game where the journey is the enjoyment, not the ending, you'll probably like FTL.

reviewText: FTL is a game that covers every beautiful aspect of the gaming industry. The game is not too hard, but at the same time, not too easy. The random events gives different experiences on every journey, some good, and some bad. The game frustrates you at times, but at others it rewards you. The main mechanic that drives the game is the Permadeath feature. No saving the game and reloading it. There is no room for error in FTL, if you are destroyed becuase you didn't purchase better weapons, tough luck. It gives a feeling of individuality. When you are on the final sector of the game, you know this is it. One way or another, you'll never see your ship again, and it makes us feel sad for the poor crew. You have to manuever and plan out as the story progresses, or else you will be destroyed. Would I recommend it? Yes. I think it is one of the best Indie titles out there. With the new expansion, the game feels even more immersive then before. One of the best improvements was added customization, the fact that every journey would be even more different then before. I give this game a 9/10, one point deducted for the head-bashing boss, which I have only beaten once on easy.

reviewText:
This is a challenging but fun and rewarding game that will test your decision making skills on the fly and the patience to endure through hardship as the losses continue to pile up. If you can remain adamant in your will to achieve victory perhaps you'll discover one of the many winning formulas that will lead you to continued success.

The general flow of the game consists of choosing a weak starship and slowly building your combat ability through weapons, crew, and supporting systems as you flee from a seemingly unstopable foe; all while trying to maintain a balance of key resources like fuel which could mean certain doom if you run out. The game features many event choices that can reward your decisions with new weapons or could cost you the life of your crew, by adding certain facilities to your ship you'll be able to choose from a more expansive list of choices that  can sway the event in your favour.

The combat consists of two ships (yours and your foes) divided via a split screen, while waiting for your weapons to charge you can shuffle the power around your ship to boost different systems, have you ever wanted to yell something like Diverge all power from the engines into forward shields."? Well now you can. When you weapons have finished charging you can decide 'where' on the enemy ship to fire

reviewText:
FTL: Faster Than Light is a game you have to see for yourself to understand. Not only is it a game, it's a spaceship simulator. Oxygen levels can fluctuate throughout the fight, and fires can erupt toasting your crew and burning more of the precious oxygen. How will you defeat your enemy? Will you light the oxygen room ablaze and suffocate them? Send boarders over and watch the chaos ensue? EMP their shields, and blow up the weapons? Better yet, how will you respond to that?

Will you send in your shields specialist to put out the fire, but leave your shields down? Will you lock the doors and cut of oxygen and suffocate the enemy? Will you be able to reroute your crew to get the shields back online?

Ironically, hilarious failures can be half the fun of the game. Whoops, forgot to close that door. Sorry pilot, didn't mean to suffocate you. Dang, forgot my boarders on the enemy ship!

The only flaws are the harsh learning curve, and the high difficulty can be offputting for some. Despite those minor nitpicks,  overall, I give it a 9/10.

reviewText: People who think games like Dark Souls is hard have probably never played FTL before. This strategy game where you control a space-ship that is running away from the Rebel fleet in an attempt to save the galaxy is honestly one of the most difficult rouge-like's that I've ever played. There were so many times when I'd reach the final boss of the game with max health and soon find my ship completely destroyed in mere moments simply because they'd breach my defenses before I could even graze their ship. This unforgiving game only lets you have one life throughout the whole game, and finding that the game runs on the weirdest random number generator doesn't exactly make things a lot easier on the player. The different weapons and ships make this game a hell of a lot more interesting, as you constantly have to make changes to your every move throughout the entire game. One moment, you may be dominating a supply ship to the point where they try to flee; but they can't because you shot down their engines. The next, the exact same thing is happening to you. With the new Advanced Edition, the entire game pretty much was changed and rebalanced (Flak is the most OP weapon. Get as much as you can). This game deserves a 9/10, for it's only problem being that unlocking new ships is too vague for most people to get, and with it's weird random number generator it makes it nearly impossible to determine if this gameplay will get me a new ship to use"."

reviewText:
If you like Star Wars or geek over spaceships,this is the game for you. I don't, but I still caught myself rambling on about the difference between Ion and Laser weapons, how many alien races are in the game, ship types, etc. So this game sets up a science fiction world that you quickly become immersed in, and once you boot this game up, it's hard to stop playing.

As you may have seen from gameplay (or firsthand experienc), this is an RPG. Even if you don't really like RPGs, the game's space combat is easy to pick up but hard to master.

In FTL, it also helps to be lucky. Depending on that, you can get more valuable scrap material to buy weapons from stores or upgrade your ship. You can also randomly get quests to unlock more spaceships, so there is variety in that aspect to. Just don't expect to beat the game on your first try.

reviewText:
This game is great for that time when you just want to kill a bit of time, its fun, its got random events that make it interesting, and it has perma-death to add suspense. 37 hrs of play and the Crew of The Kestel are finally celebrating their first victory over the rebels. The final battle was a tense moment of Power surges VS cloaking. Lasers VS shields. Missles VS anti missle drone. and what it came down to was a slug fest, My crew huddle in one room most of my ship on fire or breached and my laser firing at his shields and weapons. in the end I won and he was space debrie.

so. After 37 hours do I still recommend the game. Hell yes, as frustrating it is to watch your finely tuned plans go up in smoke by some pirate with a drone, it all helps you to learn what you need to know for that final battle and after its all said and done beating that last boss for the first time is an awesome feeling.

reviewText: A rogue-like space mission in which you must deliver the last hope of a dying Federation in a marathon trip through several varied sectors. Your journey is restricted both by your limited fuel and the approaching Rebel fleet, so grinding isn't really an option. Each game should take around a half hour to an hour and a half and there is a nearly endless combination of weapons and modules to experiment with. Everything is controlled by very simple resources and upgrade trees, keeping the learning curve short. All great things which make for a great game. What I couldn't get over, and what drains a good portion of the fun out of this game for me, is just how random a rogue-like. It is nearly impossible to set a goal beyond survival and success. Various weapon combinations might excite you, but there is no guarantee you'll ever get a shot at testing them. The trade off here is, of course, that each playthrough is unique and if that's what you're looking for, FTL is perfect for you. However, if you look to strategy games for intense planning and not the fun a constant wrench in the works makes for, this might not be the game for you.

reviewText:
This game has been a surprise to me. Caught it in the Steam sale over Christmas and have to admit I didn't play it straight away. But casually loaded it up last week and have been hooked!

You start with a crew of 3, with a basic loadout of weapons, fuel and the ability to get some drones to assist you with tasks like ship repairs, intruders, among others. Your mission? KEEP MOVING! The rebels are chasing you from one sector to the next. On your journey you'll be encountering events such as pirates chasing down defenceless ships (do you help them? do you accept a pirate bribe to stay out of it?) and you can sell scrap you collect to upgrade your systems (buy additional crew members to help with unmanned systems, buy fuel, rockets, new weapons...). You'll never have enough scrap to outfit your ship completely so it's very important to make the right decision.

The random" element of the game is perhaps its best feature. No 2 games are the same
date: you can "jump" once and get an additional crew member
recommended: or you can jump and find yourself staring at a rebel ship wanting to shoot you to pieces.\n\n...and if you wanted more than something that was replayable
hoursPlayed: you've got a truly excellent soundtrack to listen to as you play that's atmospheric and draws you in.\n\nBest indie game I've played personally
voteText: and I'd definitely get it... whether you want it right now or whether you can wait til the next sale

reviewText:
This recommendation is a bit on the hesitant side, though I'll get to why later.

Anyway, First off, FTL: Faster than Light has a great soundtrack - and an interesting one at that. It tries to give a cinimatic feel without using orchestral instruments, and as a result it has a distinct sound. Bonus points are given for utilizing a leitmotief, and even more for making it subtle.

Graphically, there's not much to speak of. FTL has a very retro look, though kinda on the low-end of 16 bit or the high-end of 8 bit. The sprites are large and high-res, but there's no shading to speak of. The backgrounds feel a bit, well, stock, but look nice.

FTL's gameplay is easy to learn but takes a long time to master. You can get the hang of the game very quickly, but the difficulty is notable. It's not the hardest game I've played, but it's definately a challenge.

Which brings me to why I'm hesitant to recommend this game. Saying the game isn't the hardest game I've played" is not a very accurate way to judge difficulty
date: as I've played a few games that were so hard the average gamer would considder it torture (Exceed: Gun Bullet Children comes to mind). This game is definately out to get you (like any Roguelike) and is VERY obvious about it.\n\nStory-wise
recommended: FTL is pretty simple and a bit reminicent of one of the underlying plots of Star Wars
hoursPlayed: just in reverse. You've stolen the plans to the rebel flagship and are running from the rebel fleet. You must bring the plans to the federation HQ and then destroy the rebel flagship. There are a ton of side-quests and events that spice things up
voteText: and no playthrough is the same.\n\nOverall

votesHelpful: and has a great soundtrack. However

reviewText: When I first played this game I must admit that it was not the file obtained from Steam that I was using.  However, after playing FTL for a while it has become one of my favourite games and the effort that has been put into creating this game is immense, so evident in fact that I bought the game because the developers simply deserve it.  Through an intoxicating mix of luck, strategy, and permadeath, this game presents players with countless scenarios and tools that can be used to progress throughout the galaxy.  The gameplay is incredible and very rogue-esque allowing for a modern incarnation of a game viewed as a classic by many.  The atmosphere generated by the universe of the game encourages great immersion and the soundtrack within FTL is one of the best I have ever heard.  Oh, and kudos to Subset Games for their uncommon chivalry in making a huge expansion pack for the game free to all players.  This sort of thing is not seen much anymore and it is a testament to just how much the developers care about the players who have invested in this amazing experience.  I am looking forward to any new adventure that Subset develops and I will without a doubt be playing it.  FTL is an incredible game that achieves everything it sets out to achieve and more, the game deserves nothing less than full marks and I recommend it to everyone.

reviewText:
Boy...

This is a tricky one.

I'm not going to NOT recommend it. It's a good game, that's for sure, and I don't regret buying it. I've only played 7 hours so far, but there's no doubt I'll sink in some more hours so... yeah, it's a good game.

But it's really not as marvellous and great and perfect as some reviews suggest. For one thing, this game does not have awesome random events". The game IS one gigantic random event. There's really nothing you can do that you are SURE will bring in positive or negative outcomes. This total lack of control feels refreshing at times

reviewText: People who think games like Dark Souls is hard have probably never played FTL before. This strategy game where you control a space-ship that is running away from the Rebel fleet in an attempt to save the galaxy is honestly one of the most difficult rouge-like's that I've ever played. There were so many times when I'd reach the final boss of the game with max health and soon find my ship completely destroyed in mere moments simply because they'd breach my defenses before I could even graze their ship. This unforgiving game only lets you have one life throughout the whole game, and finding that the game runs on the weirdest random number generator doesn't exactly make things a lot easier on the player. The different weapons and ships make this game a hell of a lot more interesting, as you constantly have to make changes to your every move throughout the entire game. One moment, you may be dominating a supply ship to the point where they try to flee; but they can't because you shot down their engines. The next, the exact same thing is happening to you. With the new Advanced Edition, the entire game pretty much was changed and rebalanced (Flak is the most OP weapon. Get as much as you can). This game deserves a 9/10, for it's only problem being that unlocking new ships is too vague for most people to get, and with it's weird random number generator it makes it nearly impossible to determine if this gameplay will get me a new ship to use"."

reviewText:
This is a challenging but fun and rewarding game that will test your decision making skills on the fly and the patience to endure through hardship as the losses continue to pile up. If you can remain adamant in your will to achieve victory perhaps you'll discover one of the many winning formulas that will lead you to continued success.

The general flow of the game consists of choosing a weak starship and slowly building your combat ability through weapons, crew, and supporting systems as you flee from a seemingly unstopable foe; all while trying to maintain a balance of key resources like fuel which could mean certain doom if you run out. The game features many event choices that can reward your decisions with new weapons or could cost you the life of your crew, by adding certain facilities to your ship you'll be able to choose from a more expansive list of choices that  can sway the event in your favour.

The combat consists of two ships (yours and your foes) divided via a split screen, while waiting for your weapons to charge you can shuffle the power around your ship to boost different systems, have you ever wanted to yell something like Diverge all power from the engines into forward shields."? Well now you can. When you weapons have finished charging you can decide 'where' on the enemy ship to fire
date: do you want to disablew their weapons or perhaps for the more twisted at heart you may consider targetting their o2 and watching them suffocate- with greater loot to boot.\n\nThe soundtrack for ftl is very atmospheric and memorable
recommended: you'll ocassionaly find yourself humming to it. There was such a demand for the sound track that it is also available for purchase.\n\nLength
hoursPlayed: replayabiliy? An average run through the game from beginning to end with a single ship could take you anywhere from 1-5 hours

it is rather more about controlling probability. Prepare to spend at least 20 hours of experiencing loss and learning from your mistakes because the game can be beaten with relative ease once you understand how it ticks.

Great game for those willing to put somesolid effort into understanding.

reviewText: It's certainly addicting and fun, at least while you're doing well. Not to mention that using built-in exploits and leadership skills (read: tag-teaming boarders and fires, or luring said boarders into the med bay and fighting them with heals) can be pretty gratifying. However, I find a large margin of error to be the fact that it's just as fortuitous as, well, real space travel and war... in our present with our technology. Seriously, what kind of faster-than-light spaceship crew doesn't have anything better than a fire extinguisher? Why can't we isolate the cabins to vent oxygen only from the ones that are on fire? What material did they build it from that is so mysteriously flammable? And once you think you've got the timing of the weapons right and everything, and you've fully upgraded your shields and you've got decent weapons and a dependable dodge rating, the flagship puts up a kind of underwhelming fight... at least until suddenly your entire med bay is on fire and your crew drops dead because the system is too damaged for heals while you're still getting battered by the flagship but since all hands are on deck (and dying) to put out the stupid fire then your shields reload as slow as molasses in a vaccum and then you just die. Like you never even spent any time working your butt off to get your ship the best it can be, all those thrilling escapes and chases by the rebel fleet and the times you went six jumps with three hull points left and got to a repair station by the skin of your teeth, like those never even happened. And why? So you can do it all again. Nothing compared to the rush I get when I start off a fresh adventure, but it's agonizing to have to start from the bottom every time, considering this is the only permadeath-upgrade-your-way-unscripted-rpg game that I own or have ever played. No idea why I keep coming back to it, but I do and I can say I'll keep playing until it manages to really ♥♥♥♥ me off, and considering the way I died against the flagship on easy and I've still got the stomach to hit restart, I can't see myself rage-deleting the local content anytime soon.

reviewText:
A Paladin's Review: FTL: Faster Than Light. The Creator of Its Own Genre for A Reason.Genre: 2D Strategy Sci-Fi Rogue-Like.
Developed & Published by: Subset Games
Platform: Windows, Mac, Linux and Mobile.
Business Model: Base Game + Free Expansion
Copy Gifted By A Friend Read the full and unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]

Overall Gameplay Thoughts
I had seen this game get featured in various articles before its release and I'll admit that I kind of let this game slip under my radar until after release. Since this happened, I've been working on ways of preventing this from happening in the future. But I digress. After seeing what the game was about post-launch, I was interested in picking the game up very soon though lack of funds prevented me from getting the game initially. Thankfully, a good friend of mine gifted me the game. FTL: Faster Than Light is a rogue-like, real-time spaceship simulator. In FTL, you must fly your spaceship through hostile space, fight pirates, make diplomatic decisions, and avoid losing your entire crew and/or ship to the cold blackness of space. This game has you flying through various sectors of space collection equipment and scrap (currency) to improve the ship as well as meeting new races and seeing new regions of space. All the while, you must outrun the Rebel fleet that is trying to catch you before you reach the waiting Federation fleet.

The Story and Gameplay.
You're the captain of a starship for the Federation fleet that is being pursued by the overwhelming Rebel fleet. Why? Because you've learned important tactical information on how to defeat the Rebel fleet. You must deliver this information through a harrowing gauntlet of star systems and planets, avoiding overwhelming danger and surviving the odds. There are eight very dangerous sectors of space before you arrive at the Federation's Last Stand. There are up to four different paths you can take in each sector where a randomly generated situation will either benefit or debilitate your situation. After surviving the eight sectors, you'll join up with the Federation fleet to take on the invading Rebel fleet. At which point you must attack the Flagship of the Rebels directly while the Federation fleet attacks the Rebel fleet itself. Its game over if your ship or crew die at any point. For the most part, your choices have immediate consequences which will build up over time and may lead to success or failure. There are only a couple of choices you can make that will affect anything in the long-term. Generally, there are the prerequisites to acquiring new cruisers.

Each new cruiser you acquire is built and balanced differently from each other to fit a certain play-style. Some are better at stealth, some have better offensive weapons and some are better at taking over the enemy ship or removing all of the crew members. Each cruiser also comes with a B-layout that changes what crew, weapons and modules are included on your ship as well as the color of the ship. There is a great variety of ships for FTL, its just unlocking them can take a long time. When starting the game you get to choose the ship, the layout, the name of the ship and the name of your initial crew, as well as which gender your Human crew are. You can also choose the difficulty setting easy or normal. However, I think they mislabeled these and its more like hard and insane. Not that its a bad thing, but normal" is not as easy as you would think in most games. Once you've done all this
date: your ready to start out on your adventure through the stars. You can choose which planet you get to jump to from the galaxy map. Just keep in mind that every jump you make means that the rebels come that much closer to catching up to you. Even if they do
recommended: you can fight them off. Its generally not recommended because the only reward you'll get for beating them is one unit of fuel and no scrap. Scrap is the currency you use to repair your ship
hoursPlayed: buy new weapons and other miscellaneous items.\n\nWhile the main story may not be that strong
voteText: the real story is the journey you take in this harsh universe. Will you lose most of your crew in a freak accident only to survive all the way to the last sector on a wish and a prayer? Or will you escape from a sun's solar flare only to jump into an asteroid field and watch as your ship gets ripped apart by the asteroids and the nearby pirate's lasers? Or do you send your crew down to a randomly planet's distress call only to lose some of them as they are attacked by rebel forces? The story is played out with a lot of different text screens as you jump from one place in the galaxy map to the next. You'll encounter many different races
helpfulPercent: each with their own set of needs and personalities which you'll then have to decide what's best for your ship's continued survival. That's the fun with games like this is that you get to create the story in your head as you go along. It happened more than once that I would say "ENGAGE" at my monitor as my ship escaped a brutal battle or mourned over the loss of a comrade who bravely defended invading forces from taking over the ship. So
votesHelpful: while the base story might not be much
votesTotal:
its what you create from the universe that will really engage your interest in the game.

Advanced Edition Thoughts
FTL: Advanced Edition fleshes everything about the game out
votesFunny: it's that simple. The new alien race adds a new mechanic where they suck the air out of the room they are in. There's new ships as well. It also comes with more music
commentsCount: weapons
column16:
encounters to overcome and UI enhancements to boot. It's a free expansion so no reason not to enjoy it. It can be disabled if you're wanting the vanilla FTL experience.

PC Settings
FTL's settings are a bit lacking. You only have a few options to control the size of the game on your screen. Those included are: windowed mode
column17: full-screen (stretched)
column18: full-screen (black borders) and full-screen (FTL's native resolution) which is not your monitor's resolution. You also have no control over key bindings
column19: though the default keys are pretty smartly placed. There are also a bunch of other minor settings you can enable or disable to your liking and you can see in the screenshot above. Overall
column20:
my biggest criticism of the settings choices would be the lack of resolution options as I'm not a bit fan of the current ones but they should work well enough for you. The game also features a good tutorial to get you up to speed on how to play. There is also a Stats screen which contains your best performance and achievements for each ship you've flown. The game is well polished as far as being free from any bugs or crashing problems are concerned.

Final Thoughts
FTL is a fantastic game and I don't think I'm saying anything new there. There's plenty of content and challenge

column22: but there's something to enjoy every run. It's one of the few games that genuinely gives the feeling of being a starship captain. If your looking for a starship simulator that is an enjoyable
column25: then give FTL: Faster Than Light a look. This became my Game of the Year in 2012.\n\nRead this review and more on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]"

reviewText:
This game though.

You don't really pilot your ship, you omnisciently control it - and it's tough. If you don't die in the first system your first time, then you are inhuman. The game is incredibly unforgiving, and EVERY choice you make has an impact. Stranded civilian ship want to trade 5 missiles for two of your fuel? You run out of fuel before you can resupply at the next store, and die. Refuse a pirate trader and wind up fighting? The extra hull damage to your ship causes you to explode in the asteriod field down the way. As unforgiving as the game can be, it challenges you to make smart choices, and manage your ship cautiously and conservatively.

The combat is suprisingly fun, and the sound track is quite immersive - though I don't think I would buy the standalone sound track. Everything about the game keeps you coming back for more, and it's beautiful.

reviewText:
Rogue-likes: the randomized frontier.

FTL's randomness makes for some incredibly entertaining gameplay as you attempt to make the most of your trip from one side of the galaxy to the other to save the Federation, all while being chased by looming, innumerable rebel forces.

You will extermish pirates to varying degrees of glee and bitterness. You will guide that lost civilian to their destination, find out it was a rebel trap, and smile. You will relish every victory.

You will have to sell that Burst Laser III so you can upgrade your engines. You will open that Mantis escape pod because you are desperate for someone who can board ships. You will lose the last bit of your ship's HP to an unfortunately timed missle. Failing to make it to the end of a roughly 6-hour playthrough is what makes your victories significant.

FTL is visually very simple, a hallmark of its indie production, but as much as it could benefit from a bigger-than-1280x800 resolution or perhaps even 3D graphics, I love how I can run it on my integrated graphics laptop.

FTL is a tremendous value and important landmark in the history of crowdfunded games. Were I to wake up in an alternate universe where I had yet to create a Steam account, I would buy FTL again, for around three incarnations, anyway.

reviewText:
This game is glorious, but can be difficult and punishing. On your first play, your ship is probably going to be destroyed, your entire crew is going to die, and you just don't know how you are supposed to survive the harsh realities of intergalactic space travel.

Be sure to do easy mode the first few play-throughs while you figure how it works. Normal difficulty is really hard and you will probably starve for resources somewhere around sector five or six.

I initially thought this game did not have much replayability, but I was wrong. Playing with the different ships and configurations can be a real challenge and encourages different play styles.

reviewText: FTL is one of those games that, if you don't dodge out of the gate, will grab you hard.  It's got that just-one-more jump thing, kind of like Civ.  It's got that mix and match build thing, kind of like Dredmor.  But what really makes it shine is the clever meshing of several minigames, all at once - but with the ability to pause and think about your orders.  Kind of like Baldur's gate.  But it's none of those things.  Instead, it's possibly the best spaceship game I've ever played.  Right up there with 4x treats like Sins and oldschool wonders like Escape Velocity.  It just nails that space atmosphere.\n\nIt's a roguelike, it's a spacechip game, it's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ slot machine and you'll happily spend weeks yanking it's arm to fire up a new ship full of redshirts, optimistically hurtling to their doom.

This game is great fun. The ascetics are very retro and remind me of games from yesteryear. The gameplay itself is fun, challenging and highly addictive, you will want to play it through time and again. Even when the odds are against you, and they often are, you will want to fight on and try to be the hero despite your impending doom.

The in game universe is already vast and highly diverse, you never know whether the next warp will be to a friendly planet, devastated space station or rebel ambush. The whole game is more or less procedurally generated so you never have the same experience twice, which keeps it fresh each time you retry.

As the captain you manage what systems you have installed in your ship, what weapons you have equipped, even which crew members fly with you. There is even a basic rpg system for each crew member, so if they do die you feel a sense of lost. I remember getting very attached to the little guys.


This game will kick your butt and laugh at you whilst doing it yet that is a price that is very easily paid considering how enjoyment you’ll get. This is a 100% recommend even at full price, on sale you would be crazy not to get this. And due to a recent update it’s even better. There are also mods that can be applied for an even better experience, I recommend the Captain’s edition

Have fun ^_^

reviewText:
FTL: Faster Than Light is a game you have to see for yourself to understand. Not only is it a game, it's a spaceship simulator. Oxygen levels can fluctuate throughout the fight, and fires can erupt toasting your crew and burning more of the precious oxygen. How will you defeat your enemy? Will you light the oxygen room ablaze and suffocate them? Send boarders over and watch the chaos ensue? EMP their shields, and blow up the weapons? Better yet, how will you respond to that?

Will you send in your shields specialist to put out the fire, but leave your shields down? Will you lock the doors and cut of oxygen and suffocate the enemy? Will you be able to reroute your crew to get the shields back online?

Ironically, hilarious failures can be half the fun of the game. Whoops, forgot to close that door. Sorry pilot, didn't mean to suffocate you. Dang, forgot my boarders on the enemy ship!

The only flaws are the harsh learning curve, and the high difficulty can be offputting for some. Despite those minor nitpicks,  overall, I give it a 9/10.

reviewText:
This game is brilliant.

It looks simple, and it is, very simple, to learn to play. Mastering it, however, will take a lot longer.

The game revolves around your ship, fleeing Rebel forces and trying to reach the Allied Fleet. You start off with a few crew, some minor weapons, and few empty spaces on your ship for improvements and new systems. How you develop from there is entirely up to you.

You can use your scrap to upgrade your weapons, turning your ship into a powerful gunship. You have the options of buying new, stronger, weapons as the you locate stores, or traders. Or, if you are really lucky, you'll just find a random weapon floating in space.

Or, perhaps you'd like to capture enemy ships instead of destroying them. Then you want teleporters, and Mantis crewmen. Mantis are the insectoid race, and they are excellent in combat. Beam them into your enemy's ship, and watch as they tear through the crew until the ship is yours.

Of course, these are just two of the ways you can play this. With the Advanced Edition upgrade, you get new systems to play with, which provide you with even more options.

On top of all this, there is the hangar. Even if you beat the boss, there are another 9 ship classes to check out, and most of those have three variants, so there is still loads to do.

Then you have the various quests and missions to do, 8 randomly generated sectors of space to explore in each game, and even the chance of discovering a lost lost system... If you are lucky. All while on the run from the Rebel Fleet.

In short, I highly recommend this game. FTL is loads of fun, and rather addictive. And even if you do get tired of playing (eventually), there are many, many mods out there for it which will change up your gameplay.

reviewText: FTL is a game that is probably a pinnacle of certain individual's gaming enjoyment. A sci-fi, tactical, procedurally generated, customizable, spaceship game is something that I imagine quite a few people have been waiting for, even if they didn't realize it. The player takes the role of the crew of a small starship attempting to cover a certain distance of space to reach the Federation homeworld. The catch being that you are being pursued by rebel forces that are seeking to destroy you because you're carrying data that could result in the downfall of those forces. You jump from point to point interacting with rebel forces, pirates, science expeditions, galactic forces, etc., while attempting to maintian your position in front of the ever encroaching rebel force. Hijinks ensue.\n\nFTL is incredibly replayable, very challenging, rewarding, very engaging, and fun. For those who enjoy the genre it's a game that they will derive much enjoyment from, and for those who aren't sure of the genre, FTL is a great place to start. Great recommendation.

reviewText:
ENDGAME SPOILERS

Can be a fun game until you get to the end. The final boss is basically a checklist to make sure you're incredibly overpowered or have a some kind of way prepared to cheese it. Really, have so much as one weakness, and the Flagship will use it to tear down your hull to nothing. I had a fully decked out arsenal, pre-igniters, maxed cloaking. My one weakness might've been my modest crew size of 5. Then, my gunner is mind controlled. Make that 4 crew. 2 Humans board. Well, it's hard to get away without piloting the ship in the final fight. 3v2? Seems it'll have to do. Just gotta keep trying my best plugging away at the Zoltan shield. It's a bit tougher when I have to keep my weapons from taking damage when an enemy combatant I both don't want to kill yet need to constantly fight is in the same room as them. Ouch. A wayward rocket in the medbay while cycling injured fighters in. Goodbye crew member. Oh boy. 2 more humans boarding. No use in trying to man the blast doors, they're right on top of me. Just gotta vent them out into space. Now let's fix up my weapons.  Here I am with 2 crew with a silver of health left each. Could I possibly finish the fight? (cue power surge just after I cloaked to avoid a barrage)




In case you couldn't tell, no. I didn't finish the fight. And legend has it, the salt remains in the heart of this review's writer to this very day. Or not. I'm writing this at 1 AM just a few minutes after it happened. It sure feels like it'll stick with me for a long time though. Maybe I'll upload this review, if not just to relive the bad memory the next time I wonder
Wait
date: I 've reviewed games on Steam?"\n\nThat reminds me. This is supposed to be a review
recommended: not a blog to vent about my shortcomings in video games. FTL fun if you delude yourself into thinking that luck isn't the main deciding factor in runs. You always know deep down that it's something of an elaborate gamble. Sooner or later you'll remember
hoursPlayed: and it'll lose some of its appeal in gameplay. You'll see all of the beaconevents before too long
voteText: and every conceivable dramatic
helpfulPercent: emergent comeback or situation will occur to some degree if you play a bit longer. Once those lose their charm
votesHelpful: it becomes harder and harder to come back to. At least it has for me.\n\nI suppose a ten dollar indie game doens't advertise infinite replayability
votesTotal: so you know what
votesFunny: I'm going to begrudgingly reccomend it despite coming in here to fervently denounce the game with the hopes that maybe my spite would be resolved if I was lucky enough to see the positive review percentage drop by a digit following my submission. I've had a lot of frustration with this game
commentsCount: but I think overall
column16: if I look way back to 2012 (when good indie games were released on Steam on a regular basis

reviewText:
Good game quite original and unique

Pros
Unique micromanaging, combat and randomly generated gameplay.

lots of ships and variety in systems and the like allowing for unique gameplans beetween ships and ship types with
upgrades allowing for even more versatile gameplay.

A satisfying challenge.

Lots of replay value in order to get ships, ship types and unlock new quests and actually trying to beat the final boss.

good music

Cons

no real easy mode so can get frustrating for newcomers.

sometimes you can get quite unlucky with events which might frustrate some people (not personally but some might)

if you arent willing to put in the time to get quite good at the game it can be hard to unlock things and do well which can lessen the replay value (though even okay players should be able to unlock some of the ships and i really dont consider this a negative).

no multiplayer of any kind

10/10 great value for money and the cons in my eyes are more there generally rather than me actually believing them to be negatives and i really dont think multiplayer would really work for this game. I can already tell so many hours of my life will be sunk into this game.

reviewText: FTL is like one of those books where you get to make choices. You are a starship captain and it is your job to warn the Federation of the impending Rebel threat. You must decide which sectors to explore, while staying ahead of your enemy, and doing all the good things good starship captains do; like going tromping into a seemingly abandoned space station, all because of some faint life signs you can’t identify. Sometimes things will go great, like getting a new crew member or some much needed supplies, while other times ♥♥♥♥ hits the fan and everyone dies. Seeing your failed plans and bad decisions culminating in your voyage ending is soul crushing at first, but it's what makes FTL truly amazing.
